question_results.question:
COEs (confirmation of enrolments) are created through:

Answer options:
PRISMS
The local Australian Embassy/Consulate- General.
CRICOS
AEI
correct_answers: PRISMS
extracted_answers: PRISMS
question_results.full_response:
## Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) Creation in Australia: A Detailed Report

The process of obtaining a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) is a critical step for international students seeking to study in Australia. Understanding the entities involved in the creation and management of COEs is essential for navigating the Australian student visa application process effectively. This report aims to clarify which entity is responsible for creating COEs, drawing upon available information to provide a comprehensive and objective analysis.

### Core Question: Who Creates COEs?

Based on the provided information, COEs (Confirmation of Enrolments) are created through the Provider Registration and International Student Management System (PRISMS).

### In-Depth Analysis

To fully understand the role of PRISMS in COE creation, it's important to define what a COE is and its significance in the Australian international education landscape.

#### What is a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE)?

A Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) is an official document issued by Australian educational institutions registered with the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) ([UniCreds Blog](https://unicreds.com/blog/coe-for-australia/)). It serves as proof that an international student has been accepted into a CRICOS-registered course and has met the necessary requirements to commence their studies in Australia ([UniCreds Blog](https://unicreds.com/blog/coe-for-australia/)). The COE is a mandatory document for international students applying for an Australian student visa (subclass 500) ([SWEC Visa Consultant](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).

The COE typically includes the following information ([UniCreds Blog](https://unicreds.com/blog/coe-for-australia/)):

*   Student's personal details: Full name, passport number, date of birth, nationality
*   Course details: Course name, course code, CRICOS code, estimated tuition fees, duration of study
*   Institution details: Institution name, contact information, provider number
*   Additional information: Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) details, any applicable conditions

#### The Role of PRISMS

PRISMS (Provider Registration and International Student Management System) is an essential tool for managing and monitoring international student data in Australia ([Meshed Higher-Ed Online Resources](https://meshedgroup.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HigherEdResources/pages/2489057891/PRISMS+Provider+Registration+and+International+Student+Management+System)). Managed by the Australian Department of Education, PRISMS enables education providers to comply with the requirements of the Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act ([Meshed Higher-Ed Online Resources](https://meshedgroup.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HigherEdResources/pages/2489057891/PRISMS+Provider+Registration+and+International+Student+Management+System)). The system allows for the electronic issuance of Confirmation of Enrolments (CoEs), crucial for student visa applications, and helps track the enrolment status and course progress of international students ([Meshed Higher-Ed Online Resources](https://meshedgroup.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HigherEdResources/pages/2489057891/PRISMS+Provider+Registration+and+International+Student+Management+System)).

#### How PRISMS Facilitates COE Creation

Educational institutions registered with CRICOS use PRISMS to create and issue CoEs to eligible international students. The process involves the following steps:

1.  **Student Application and Acceptance:** The student applies to a CRICOS-registered institution and receives an offer of admission.
2.  **Acceptance and Fee Payment:** The student accepts the offer and pays the required tuition fees ([SWEC Visa Consultant](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).
3.  **CoE Creation in PRISMS:** The institution uses PRISMS to create a CoE for the student, entering all the necessary information, including student details, course details, and institution details ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/prisms-modernisation-project/resources/prisms-coe-create-input-data-requirements)).
4.  **CoE Issuance:** Once the CoE is created and approved within PRISMS, the institution issues the CoE to the student, usually electronically ([SWEC Visa Consultant](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).
5.  **Visa Application:** The student includes the CoE in their student visa application to the Department of Home Affairs ([SWEC Visa Consultant](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).

#### The Significance of CRICOS Registration

The Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) is a register of Australian education providers and courses that are approved to offer education to international students ([International Education](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/about-AEI/Pages/PRISMS-FAQs.aspx)). Only CRICOS-registered institutions have the authority to issue CoEs ([SWEC Visa Consultant](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)). This registration ensures that the institution meets Australian government standards for providing education to international students ([SWEC Visa Consultant](https://swecvisaconsultant.com/how-to-get-a-confirmation-of-enrolment-coe-for-an-australian-student-visa/)).

#### The ESOS Act

The *Education Services for Overseas Students Act 2000* (ESOS Act) sets out the legal framework for the regulation of education and training providers offering courses to overseas students ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/resources/faqs/cricoselicos-compliance)). The ESOS Act aims to protect the interests of international students, ensure the quality of education and training, and maintain the integrity of Australia's international education sector ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/resources/faqs/cricoselicos-compliance)). PRISMS helps education providers comply with the requirements of the ESOS Act by providing a system for managing and monitoring international student data ([Meshed Higher-Ed Online Resources](https://meshedgroup.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HigherEdResources/pages/2489057891/PRISMS+Provider+Registration+and+International+Student+Management+System)).

#### Recent Changes and Updates

Several sources indicate that Australia has been implementing stricter requirements for student visas, including mandatory CoEs for onshore applications starting in 2025 ([Visa and Immigrations](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-mandatory-coe-for-student-visas-in-2025-what-you-need-to-know/)). This change aims to ensure that only genuine students are granted visas and to prevent misuse of the student visa system ([Visa and Immigrations](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-mandatory-coe-for-student-visas-in-2025-what-you-need-to-know/)). Furthermore, there's a cap on international student enrollments, signaling a shift in Australia's education migration strategy ([Visa and Immigrations](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)).

#### Alternatives to CoE

While a CoE is generally required, there are exceptions. Students enrolled in a full-time course of study or training under a scholarship scheme approved by the Australian Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, sponsored by the Australian Department of Defence, or secondary exchange students may provide alternative forms of evidence ([CRICOS](https://www.cricos.com.au/eligibility/)).

#### PRISMS Modernisation Project

The PRISMS Modernisation Project is an initiative aimed at upgrading and enhancing the Provider Registration and International Student Management System (PRISMS) in Australia ([Meshed Higher-Ed Online Resources](https://meshedgroup.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HigherEdResources/pages/2489057891/PRISMS+Provider+Registration+and+International+Student+Management+System)). This project focuses on improving the functionality, user experience, and overall efficiency of PRISMS. Key objectives include streamlining processes for education providers, enhancing data accuracy and security, and ensuring better compliance with the Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act ([Meshed Higher-Ed Online Resources](https://meshedgroup.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/HigherEdResources/pages/2489057891/PRISMS+Provider+Registration+and+International+Student+Management+System)).

### Addressing the Incorrect Options

*   **The local Australian Embassy/Consulate-General:** Australian embassies and consulates do not issue CoEs. Their role is primarily related to visa processing and providing consular services.
*   **CRICOS:** CRICOS is the register of institutions and courses, not the system for creating CoEs.
*   **AEI:** While the exact meaning of AEI isn't clear from the provided context, it is unlikely to be the entity responsible for COE creation.

### Conclusion

Based on the available information, the creation of Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) documents is facilitated through the Provider Registration and International Student Management System (PRISMS). PRISMS is managed by the Australian Department of Education and is used by CRICOS-registered educational institutions to issue CoEs to eligible international students. The CoE is a critical document for international students applying for an Australian student visa, and its creation is subject to strict regulations and guidelines.

question_results.question:
Legislation and regulations in Australia relating to the enrolment of international students are:

Answer options:
The ESOS Act 2000 and The National Code of Practice 2018
The National Code of practice on student developments within Australia and The Australia Act 1986
The ESOS Act 2000 and The Migration Act 1958
The Migration Act 1958 and The Australia Act 1901
correct_answers: The ESOS Act 2000 and The National Code of Practice 2018
extracted_answers: The ESOS Act 2000 and The National Code of Practice 2018
question_results.full_response:
Here is a detailed report on the legislation and regulations in Australia relating to the enrollment of international students, adhering to all specified guidelines:

### Legislation and Regulations Governing International Student Enrollment in Australia**Introduction**

Australia has emerged as a prominent destination for international students, owing to its high standards of education and diverse cultural environment. To ensure the quality of education and protect the rights and welfare of international students, the Australian government has established a robust legislative framework. This report aims to identify the key pieces of legislation and regulations governing the enrollment of international students in Australia, providing a comprehensive overview of their roles and significance. Based on the provided information, the primary legislation and regulations are the ESOS Act 2000 and the National Code of Practice 2018.

**Core Legislation and Regulations**

The correct answer is: The ESOS Act 2000 and The National Code of Practice 2018.

**The Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000**

The Education Services for Overseas Students Act 2000 (ESOS Act) is the cornerstone of the regulatory framework for international education in Australia ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/Information-for-Students.aspx)). This Act and its related laws set out the requirements for education providers who deliver services to international students on student visas. The ESOS Act aims to protect international students and ensure they meet their visa conditions by attending classes and making satisfactory progress in their studies ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

**Key Objectives and Provisions**

1.  **Quality Assurance:** The ESOS Act ensures that education and training institutions offering courses to international students maintain high standards of quality ([teqsa.gov.au](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act)).

2.  **Tuition Fee Protection:** It provides tuition fee protection for international students, ensuring that their investment in education is safeguarded ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

3.  **Visa Integrity:** The Act supports the integrity of the student visa program by setting standards for education providers and ensuring students comply with their visa conditions ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

4.  **Registration and Obligations:** The Australian Government Department of Education administers the ESOS Act, overseeing the registration process and obligations of registered international education providers ([teqsa.gov.au](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act)).

5.  **Enforcement and Compliance:** The Act includes enforcement and compliance arrangements to address breaches, which are treated seriously and can result in significant penalties ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

**Recent Changes and Reviews**

The Australian Government has recently made changes to the ESOS Act to enhance its effectiveness and efficiency ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/Information-for-Students.aspx)). These changes are designed to make the Act stronger, simpler, and smarter. A comprehensive review of the ESOS legislation was completed in 2010 (the Baird Review), leading to further reforms ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/Information-for-Students.aspx)).

**The National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018**

The National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 (National Code 2018) is a crucial component of the ESOS framework ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)). It sets nationally consistent standards for the delivery of courses to overseas students and ensures the protection of their rights and welfare ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx)).

**Key Standards and Requirements**

1.  **Consistent Standards:** The National Code provides 15 nationally consistent standards for the professional conduct of education providers and the registration of their courses on the Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/Information-for-Students.aspx)).

2.  **CRICOS Registration:** Only CRICOS-registered courses can be offered to international students studying in Australia on a student visa ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/Information-for-Students.aspx)).

3.  **Compliance:** Education institutions must comply with the National Code to maintain their registration and provide education services to international students ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

4.  **Factsheets and Guidance:** The Department of Education provides factsheets and guidance to help registered providers understand and implement the National Code effectively ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx)).

**Specific Standards Covered by the National Code**

The National Code covers a wide range of standards, including:

*   Marketing information and practices ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

*   Recruitment of overseas students ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

*   Formalization of enrollment and written agreements ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

*   Education agents ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

*   Younger overseas students ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

*   Overseas student support services ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

*   Overseas student transfers ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

*   Overseas student visa requirements ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

*   Deferring, suspending, or canceling the overseas student’s enrollment ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

*   Complaints and appeals ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

*   Additional requirements ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx))

**Other Relevant Legislative Instruments**

In addition to the ESOS Act and the National Code, several other legislative instruments contribute to the framework for international students:

1.  **Education Services for Overseas Students Regulations:** These regulations provide detailed rules and procedures for implementing the ESOS Act ([teqsa.gov.au](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act)).

2.  **Education Services for Overseas Students (Registration Charges) Act:** This Act governs the fees and charges associated with the registration of education providers ([teqsa.gov.au](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act)).

3.  **ELICOS National Standards:** These standards outline specific quality requirements for registered providers delivering English language courses to overseas students ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

4.  **National Standards for Foundation Programs:** These standards are designed to equip international students with the skills and capabilities to seek entry into higher education programs in Australia ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

**Why Other Options Are Incorrect**

*   **The National Code of practice on student developments within Australia and The Australia Act 1986:** The National Code focuses on the conduct of education providers, not student developments. The Australia Act 1986 deals with the sovereignty and independence of Australia from the UK, not international student enrollment ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_Act_1986)).

*   **The ESOS Act 2000 and The Migration Act 1958:** While the ESOS Act is directly relevant, the Migration Act 1958 primarily governs immigration to Australia, including visa requirements, but does not specifically address the educational aspects of international student enrollment ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Migration_Act_1958)).

*   **The Migration Act 1958 and The Australia Act 1901:** The Migration Act 1958 is relevant to visa issues, but the Australia Act 1901 (more accurately, the Immigration Restriction Act 1901, replaced by the Migration Act 1958) is outdated and irrelevant to current international student regulations ([en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Migration_Act_1958)).

**Conclusion**

In conclusion, the legislative and regulatory framework governing the enrollment of international students in Australia is primarily based on the ESOS Act 2000 and the National Code of Practice 2018. These instruments ensure quality education, protect student rights, and maintain the integrity of the student visa program. While other laws like the Migration Act 1958 play a role in immigration and visa processes, the ESOS Act and the National Code are the most directly relevant to the educational experience of international students in Australia. This framework is continuously reviewed and updated to meet the evolving needs of the international education sector, reinforcing Australia's commitment to providing a high-quality and supportive environment for international students.

**References**

*   [classic.austlii.edu.au](https://classic.austlii.edu.au/au/legis/cth/num_act/aa1986114/)
*   [acu.edu.au](https://www.acu.edu.au/Handbook/Handbook-2025/unit/LAWS503)
*   [desklib.com](https://desklib.com/study-documents/australian-migration-report/)
*   [education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)
*   [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Australia_Act_1986)
*   [en.wikipedia.org](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Migration_Act_1958)
*   [idp.com](https://www.idp.com/india/blog/legal-rights-of-international-students-in-australia/)
*   [internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/Pages/default.aspx)
*   [internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/Information-for-Students.aspx)
*   [internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Pages/National-Code-2018-Factsheets-.aspx)
*   [teqsa.gov.au](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act)
*   [education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/national-code-practice-providers-education-and-training-overseas-students-2018)

question_results.question:
Which of the following circumstances is NOT reported online through PRISMS by an educational institution:

Answer options:
Students non-attendance
Students failing to meet course requirements
Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation.
Both B and C
correct_answers: Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation.
extracted_answers: Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation.
question_results.full_response:
# Reporting Obligations for CRICOS Providers in Australia: A Detailed Analysis

The Australian government, through the Australian Skills Quality Authority (ASQA) and the Department of Education, Skills and Employment (DESE), mandates specific reporting obligations for CRICOS (Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students) providers to maintain the integrity of the overseas student visa framework. These obligations are primarily managed through the Provider Registration and International Student Management System (PRISMS). This report aims to analyze which of the provided circumstances are *not* reported online through PRISMS by educational institutions, based on the given information. The answer options are:

A. Students non-attendance
B. Students failing to meet course requirements
C. Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation.
D. Both B and C

## CRICOS Provider Reporting Obligations: An Overview

CRICOS providers play a crucial role in the regulation of the Vocational Education and Training (VET) and English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students (ELICOS) sectors. They are required to report various student-related details and course variations through PRISMS to ensure compliance with the Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000 and the National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018 ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/frequently-asked-questions)).

### Key Reporting Areas

The primary areas that CRICOS providers must report on include:

1.  **Student Information:** This encompasses a student’s full name, gender, date of birth, country of birth, nationality, and contact details. For students under 18, the details of a legal guardian are also required ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/guide-reporting-obligations-cricos-providers/what-information-do-you-need-report)).
2.  **Course Details:** This includes the unique identifier of the course (CRICOS course code), agreed starting date, expected completion date, tuition fees received, and any non-tuition fees ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/guide-reporting-obligations-cricos-providers/what-information-do-you-need-report)).
3.  **Course Variations:** Any changes to a student’s course, such as changes in duration, deferrals, suspensions, or terminations, must be reported ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/guide-reporting-obligations-cricos-providers/what-information-do-you-need-report)).
4.  **Non-Commencement and Termination:** Providers must notify DESE if a student does not commence their course or terminates their enrolment before completion ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/guide-reporting-obligations-cricos-providers/what-information-do-you-need-report)).
5.  **Education Agent Information:** If a student is recruited through an education agent, the agent’s details must be provided ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/guide-reporting-obligations-cricos-providers/what-information-do-you-need-report)).
6.  **Tuition Fees:** Providers must report information about course tuition fees received each month, including the amount, payment date, and the period to which the payment relates ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/guide-reporting-obligations-cricos-providers/what-information-do-you-need-report)).

## Analysis of the Answer Options

To determine which circumstance is *not* reported through PRISMS, let's examine each option in detail.

### A. Students Non-Attendance

Student attendance is a critical aspect of monitoring overseas students' compliance with their visa conditions. CRICOS providers are required to monitor student attendance and implement intervention strategies for students who are absent for more than 5 days without approval or who are at risk of not meeting attendance requirements ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/esos-providers/esos-requirements/overseas-student-attendance)).

If a student’s attendance falls below satisfactory levels, the provider must report the student in PRISMS. However, it’s important to note that reporting is not solely based on attendance. According to ASQA, a provider may decide *not* to report a student for breaching attendance requirements if the student is:

*   Attending at least 70% of the scheduled course contact hours.
*   For ELICOS students, they demonstrate and provide evidence of a genuine compassionate or compelling circumstance.
*   For VET students, they are maintaining satisfactory course progress ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/esos-providers/esos-requirements/overseas-student-attendance)).

Therefore, while non-attendance is a factor, the decision to report depends on the specific circumstances and whether the student is meeting other requirements.

### B. Students Failing to Meet Course Requirements

CRICOS providers are obligated to monitor the course progress of each student to ensure they can complete the course within the expected duration specified on their Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) ([National Code Part D, Standard 9](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD9.aspx)). If a student is at risk of not meeting course progress requirements, the provider must implement intervention strategies to assist the student ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/esos-providers/esos-requirements/overseas-student-attendance)).

If a student is not making satisfactory course progress, the provider must report the student through PRISMS ([National Code Part D, Standard 9](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD9.aspx)). This is particularly relevant if the intervention strategy leads to the student being unable to complete the course within the expected duration.

### C. Students Finishing Their ELICOS Course One Week Later Due to Approved Vacation

This scenario involves a student extending their ELICOS course by one week due to an approved vacation. The key question is whether this extension requires reporting through PRISMS.

According to the provided information, CRICOS providers must report any changes to a student’s course duration ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/guide-reporting-obligations-cricos-providers/what-information-do-you-need-report)). This includes deferrals and suspensions, which require the provider to inform the Department of Education of any deferral or extension of a student’s course and the reasons for this variation ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/guide-reporting-obligations-cricos-providers/provider-reporting-obligations)).

However, the context of the extension is crucial. If the vacation was pre-approved and the extension of one week does not significantly impact the student's ability to meet the course requirements or visa conditions, it may not necessitate a formal report through PRISMS. The National Code emphasizes monitoring student progress to ensure completion within the expected duration ([National Code Part D, Standard 9](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD9.aspx)). A minor extension due to approved vacation, which does not jeopardize this, might fall under the provider's internal management rather than a mandatory PRISMS report.

## Determining the Correct Answer

Based on the analysis:

*   **A. Students non-attendance:** Is reported if attendance falls below 70% and the student does not have compassionate or compelling circumstances or is not maintaining satisfactory course progress.
*   **B. Students failing to meet course requirements:** Is reported if the student is not making satisfactory progress, especially if intervention strategies are ineffective.
*   **C. Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation:** May not be reported if the extension is minor and does not significantly impact the student's ability to meet course requirements or visa conditions.

Therefore, the circumstance that is *least likely* to be reported online through PRISMS is **C. Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation**, assuming the extension is minor and pre-approved.

## Conclusion

The correct answer is **C. Students finishing their ELICOS course one week later due to approved vacation.** While CRICOS providers must report changes to course duration, a minor, pre-approved extension due to vacation is less likely to require a formal report through PRISMS compared to non-attendance or failing to meet course requirements, which directly impact a student's ability to comply with visa conditions and complete their studies successfully. The reporting obligations are designed to ensure the integrity of the student visa framework and the quality of education provided to overseas students.

## References

ASQA. (n.d.). *Guide to reporting obligations for CRICOS providers/what information do you need to report?*. Australian Skills Quality Authority. [https://www.asqa.gov.au/guide-reporting-obligations-cricos-providers/what-information-do-you-need-report](https://www.asqa.gov.au/guide-reporting-obligations-cricos-providers/what-information-do-you-need-report)

ASQA. (n.d.). *ESOS providers/ESOS requirements/overseas student attendance*. Australian Skills Quality Authority. [https://www.asqa.gov.au/esos-providers/esos-requirements/overseas-student-attendance](https://www.asqa.gov.au/esos-providers/esos-requirements/overseas-student-attendance)

Department of Education, Australian Government. (n.d.). *PRISMS FAQs*. [https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/frequently-asked-questions](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/frequently-asked-questions)

National Code Part D, Standard 9. (n.d.). *National Code Part D, Standard 9*. [https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD9.aspx](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD9.aspx)

Answer options:
The hospital is unable to release the student from hospital.
The student will not receive any letters about their possible non-compliance with visa conditions
The student will be deported from Australia for not providing current information to its education provider.
The student will not be believed when he tells the institution he was sick.
correct_answers: The student will not receive any letters about their possible non-compliance with visa conditions
extracted_answers: The student will not receive any letters about their possible non-compliance with visa conditions
question_results.full_response:
## Report on the Implications of a Student's Failure to Provide a Current Address to Their Australian Education Provider

**Introduction**

This report addresses the potential consequences for an international student in Australia who has been hospitalized and has not provided their education provider with a current address. The scenario raises concerns about the student's compliance with visa conditions and the potential ramifications for their ability to continue their studies in Australia. This report will analyze the provided answer options in light of relevant Australian regulations and guidelines governing international students, particularly the *Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000* and the *National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018*.

**Analysis of Answer Options**

Let's examine each of the provided answer options to determine their validity:

1.  **The hospital is unable to release the student from hospital.**

    This option is highly unlikely. Hospitals are primarily concerned with the health and well-being of their patients. While providing contact information is standard procedure for administrative purposes, a hospital would not typically withhold a patient's release solely based on the lack of a current address. Medical professionals are bound by ethical codes and legal obligations to prioritize patient care and safety. Unless there are specific legal or medical reasons to detain the student, the hospital would likely proceed with discharge once the student is deemed fit to leave.

2.  **The student will not receive any letters about their possible non-compliance with visa conditions.**

    This option is the most plausible and directly related to the student's responsibility to maintain accurate contact information with their education provider. According to the *ESOS Act 2000* and the *National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018*, education providers are obligated to monitor international students' engagement in learning and their academic progress ([Australian Skills Quality Authority (ASQA)](https://www.asqa.gov.au/news-events/news/sector-alert-provider-responsibilities-when-using-education-agents)). This includes tracking attendance, assessment submissions, and overall academic performance. If a student is not meeting the required standards, the provider is required to intervene and offer support. Failure to improve could lead to the provider reporting the student to the Department of Home Affairs for potential visa non-compliance.

    Without a current address, the education provider would be unable to send the student any formal notifications regarding their academic progress, attendance, or potential breaches of visa conditions. This lack of communication could have serious consequences for the student, as they would be unaware of any issues and unable to take corrective action.

3.  **The student will be deported from Australia for not providing current information to its education provider.**

    While failing to provide current contact information is a serious matter, immediate deportation is not the most likely outcome. The process for addressing visa breaches is typically more nuanced. If the education provider reports the student for non-compliance, the Department of Home Affairs would likely investigate the matter. The student would generally be given an opportunity to explain their situation and provide updated information. Deportation would typically be a last resort, considered only after other avenues have been exhausted and the student has failed to rectify the breach of visa conditions.

4.  **The student will not be believed when he tells the institution he was sick.**

    This option is less likely, as medical documentation from the hospital should serve as sufficient evidence of the student's illness. While the lack of a current address might raise some initial questions, the institution is unlikely to dismiss the student's explanation outright, especially with supporting medical evidence. Education providers generally have student support services that can assist students facing difficulties, including illness ([Kangaroo Education Australia](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)).

**Conclusion**

Based on the analysis of the provided information and relevant regulations, the most accurate answer is: **The student will not receive any letters about their possible non-compliance with visa conditions.**

**Detailed Explanation**

The *Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Framework* is designed to protect international students and maintain the integrity of Australia's education system ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)). The *ESOS Act 2000* and the *National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018* outline the responsibilities of both education providers and international students.

**Responsibilities of Education Providers**

Education providers have several key responsibilities under the *ESOS Framework*, including:

*   **Monitoring Student Engagement:** Providers must monitor international students' engagement in learning and their academic progress ([Australian Skills Quality Authority (ASQA)](https://www.asqa.gov.au/news-events/news/sector-alert-provider-responsibilities-when-using-education-agents)). This includes tracking attendance, assessment submissions, and overall academic performance.
*   **Providing Support:** Providers are expected to offer support services to international students who are struggling with their studies or facing other challenges ([Kangaroo Education Australia](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)).
*   **Reporting Non-Compliance:** If a student is not meeting the required standards or is in breach of their visa conditions, the provider is obligated to report this to the Department of Home Affairs.
*   **Maintaining Accurate Records:** Providers must maintain accurate records of student contact details and other relevant information.**Responsibilities of International Students**

International students also have several key responsibilities, including:

*   **Complying with Visa Conditions:** Students must comply with all the conditions of their student visa, including attending classes, maintaining satisfactory academic progress, and not working more than the allowed hours ([VisaVerge](https://www.visaverge.com/australiaimmigration/consequences-of-exceeding-work-hours-on-a-student-visa-in-australia/)).
*   **Informing Provider of Address Changes:** Students are required to inform their education provider of any changes to their address or contact details.
*   **Maintaining Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC):** Students must maintain valid OSHC for the duration of their stay in Australia.
*   **Attending Mandatory Assessment Activities:** Students must attend all mandatory assessment activities and participate in intervention strategies if required ([Kangaroo Education Australia](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)).

**Consequences of Non-Compliance**

Failure to comply with visa conditions can have serious consequences for international students, including:

*   **Visa Cancellation:** The Department of Home Affairs can cancel a student's visa if they are found to be in breach of their visa conditions.
*   **Deportation:** If a student's visa is cancelled, they may be deported from Australia.
*   **Difficulty Obtaining Future Visas:** A history of visa breaches can make it difficult for a student to obtain future visas to Australia or other countries.

**Mitigating the Risks**

To mitigate the risks associated with non-compliance, international students should:

*   **Understand Their Visa Conditions:** Students should carefully read and understand the conditions of their student visa.
*   **Maintain Accurate Contact Information:** Students should ensure that their education provider has their current address and contact details.
*   **Seek Support When Needed:** Students should seek help from their institution's student support services if they are struggling with their studies or facing other challenges.
*   **Comply with Working Hour Restrictions:** Students must adhere to the working hour restrictions on their visa, which generally allow for 40 hours per fortnight during study periods and unlimited hours during breaks ([VisaVerge](https://www.visaverge.com/australiaimmigration/consequences-of-exceeding-work-hours-on-a-student-visa-in-australia/)).
*   **Attend Classes Regularly:** Students should attend classes regularly and maintain satisfactory academic progress.

**The Tuition Protection Service (TPS)**

The Tuition Protection Service (TPS) is an Australian Government initiative that assists international students on student visas whose education providers are unable to fully deliver their course of study ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)). The TPS ensures that students receive a refund of their unspent tuition fees or are offered a place in an alternative course if their provider defaults.

**Conclusion**

In conclusion, the scenario presented highlights the importance of international students maintaining accurate contact information with their education providers. While the hospital is unlikely to withhold the student's release, the lack of a current address could prevent the student from receiving important notifications regarding their academic progress and potential visa non-compliance. This could ultimately lead to more serious consequences, such as visa cancellation and deportation. It is crucial for international students to understand their responsibilities under the *ESOS Framework* and to take proactive steps to ensure compliance with their visa conditions.

***

**References**

Australian Skills Quality Authority (ASQA). (2022, November 4). *Sector alert: Provider responsibilities when using education agents*. [https://www.asqa.gov.au/news-events/news/sector-alert-provider-responsibilities-when-using-education-agents](https://www.asqa.gov.au/news-events/news/sector-alert-provider-responsibilities-when-using-education-agents)

Department of Education, Australian Government. (n.d.). *Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Framework*. [https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)

Department of Education, Australian Government. (n.d.). *International Providers*. [https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)

Kangaroo Education Australia. (n.d.). *Navigating Australian Student Visa Requirements in 2025: A Beginner’s Guide*. [https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)

VisaVerge. (2025, February 19). *Consequences of Exceeding Work Hours on a Student Visa in Australia*. [https://www.visaverge.com/australiaimmigration/consequences-of-exceeding-work-hours-on-a-student-visa-in-australia/](https://www.visaverge.com/australiaimmigration/consequences-of-exceeding-work-hours-on-a-student-visa-in-australia/)

question_results.question:
A student you recruited to study in Australia has contacted you. Their school has been forced to close down and they will no longer be able to attend classes. Which of the following is likely to happen to the student because their school is closing:

Answer options:
The student will have to go back to their home country because they will no longer be enrolled at a school in Australia. The school will cancel their visa and help them move back to home. The student will receive a refund from the School.
The student will have to go back to their home country because they will no longer be enrolled at a school in Australia. The student will be unable to recover their tuition fees.
The student should be able to transfer to another school in Australia because their status as an international student is protected by the ESOS Act 2000 and the Tuition Protection Service (TPS).
None of the above.
correct_answers: The student should be able to transfer to another school in Australia because their status as an international student is protected by the ESOS Act 2000 and the Tuition Protection Service (TPS).
extracted_answers: The student should be able to transfer to another school in Australia because their status as an international student is protected by the ESOS Act 2000 and the Tuition Protection Service (TPS).
question_results.full_response:
## Report on Options for International Students Affected by School Closures in Australia

The closure of an educational institution can create significant uncertainty and disruption for international students studying in Australia. This report examines the options available to a student whose school has closed, focusing on the protections afforded by the *Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000* and the *Tuition Protection Service (TPS)*. Based on the available information, the most appropriate course of action for the student is to transfer to another school in Australia, as their status as an international student is protected by the ESOS Act 2000 and the Tuition Protection Service (TPS).

### Legal Framework: ESOS Act 2000 and National Code

The *Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000* and its related instruments form the legal foundation for the quality assurance of education and training institutions offering courses to international students in Australia ([Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act)). The ESOS framework ensures that training providers meet nationally consistent standards in education delivery, facilities, and services, and it provides tuition fee protection for international students ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)). Breaches of the ESOS Act are treated seriously, and penalties can be significant ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

The *National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018* (National Code 2018) sets nationally consistent standards for the delivery of courses to overseas students ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)). Education institutions must comply with the National Code to maintain their registration to provide education services to international students ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

### The Role of the Tuition Protection Service (TPS)

Australia's *Tuition Protection Service (TPS)* is a government-run organization designed to protect international students when an education provider defaults ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)). In the event of a school closure, the TPS will work with the affected students to find a similar course at a different education provider, facilitating a transfer to another institution to ensure the student's education continues with minimal disruption ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)). If an alternative course cannot be found, or the student does not wish to continue their studies, the TPS will arrange for a refund of the unused portion of their tuition fees ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).

The TPS has been actively involved in assisting international students affected by recent education provider closures. For example, in 2024 and 2025, the TPS activated to support students affected by the closures of Move Academy, United Pop Australia, Western Sydney Technology College, JP International College, Bruce Hartwig Flying School, Kingston Institute Australia, The Malka Group, IH Sydney Training Services Pty Ltd, and Gills College Australia Pty Ltd ([Department of Education](https://www.education.gov.au/notices/tps)). These instances demonstrate the TPS's role in safeguarding the interests of international students during provider defaults.

### Student Visa Considerations

It is a condition of a student visa that the holder remains enrolled in a registered course ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-students)). If an education provider defaults, it is crucial for the student to enroll in an alternative course to maintain their visa status ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-students)). The *Department of Home Affairs* website provides further information about how an education provider default can affect a student visa ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-students)).

Once a student finds a new course, they need to update their visa information via *ImmiAccount* to reflect the new provider and course details ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)). Acting quickly and working with an education agent and the TPS is essential to ensure a smooth transfer to a new course or institution ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)). Failure to take action could affect the student's visa, potentially leading to cancellation ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).### Key Actions for Affected Students

When a school closes, international students should take the following steps:

1.  **Contact TPS and Education Agent:** Contact the education agent and visit the TPS website to contact their support team ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).
2.  **Look for Alternative Institutions:** Work with the TPS to find alternative study options that align with their course and academic goals ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).
3.  **Notify the Department of Home Affairs:** Update visa information via ImmiAccount once a new course is secured ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).
4.  **Secure Documentation:** Obtain all academic records (transcripts, certificates, etc.) as soon as possible, as these documents will be important when transferring to a new course or applying for a refund through the TPS ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).
5.  **Clarify Costs and Fees:** Clarify all fee-related questions with the new provider, education agent, and the TPS, as costs associated with transferring to a new institution might not be covered ([Pathway to Aus](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)).

### Updated Student Visa Rules for 2025

While the ESOS Act and TPS provide a safety net for international students, it is important to be aware of recent changes to student visa rules in Australia. In 2025, Australia implemented stricter guidelines for student visa applicants to ensure they are genuine students ([Visa Verge](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)). These changes include:

*   **Certificate of Enrollment (CoE) Requirement:** A CoE is now required for most student visa applications ([Visa Verge](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).
*   **Increased Financial Costs:** Applicants must demonstrate sufficient financial resources to cover tuition fees and living expenses ([Visa Verge](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)). The application fee is AUD 1,600 ([Visa Verge](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).
*   **Limitations on Onshore Applications:** The updated policy restricts onshore applications for candidates on temporary visas, such as visitor visas, unless they meet all requirements, including holding a CoE ([Visa Verge](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).
*   **National Planning Level (NPL) Cap:** A cap of 270,000 new international student commencements has been enforced for 2025 to manage the growing number of international students ([Visa and Immigrations](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)).

These changes aim to balance Australia's education sector's expansion with infrastructure and economic sustainability ([Visa and Immigrations](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)).### Conclusion

In conclusion, the most likely outcome for the student in this scenario is that they should be able to transfer to another school in Australia. This is because their status as an international student is protected by the *ESOS Act 2000* and the *Tuition Protection Service (TPS)*. The TPS will assist the student in finding a suitable alternative course and institution, ensuring minimal disruption to their education. While the student must take prompt action to maintain their visa status and comply with the updated student visa rules for 2025, the ESOS framework and TPS provide a robust safety net to protect their interests.

### References

Department of Education, Australian Government. (n.d.). *Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Framework - Department of Education, Australian Government*. [https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)

Department of Education, Australian Government. (n.d.). *International Students - Department of Education, Australian Government*. [https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-students](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-students)

Department of Education. (n.d.). *Education Provider Notices | Department of Education*. [https://www.education.gov.au/notices/tps](https://www.education.gov.au/notices/tps)

Pathway to Aus. (n.d.). *School Closed: A Guide For International Students In Australia*. [https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/](https://pathwaytoaus.com/general/school-closed-a-guide-for-international-student-in-australia/)

Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency. (n.d.). *ESOS Act | Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency*. [https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/how-we-regulate/acts-and-standards/esos-act)

Visa and Immigrations. (2025, February 13). *Australia’s New Student Visa Rules for 2025: Key Changes and What You Need to Know*. [https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)

Visa Verge. (2025, January 25). *Australia Updates Student Visa Rules for 2025 to Ensure Genuine Applicants*. [https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)

question_results.full_response:
# The Tuition Protection Service and the ESOS Act 2000: A Detailed Report

The Australian government has established a robust framework to protect international students studying in Australia. A key component of this framework is the Tuition Protection Service (TPS), which safeguards the tuition fees of international students in the event that their education provider defaults. Determining the legislative basis for the TPS is crucial to understanding its operation and scope. This report aims to identify the specific legislation that outlines the Tuition Protection Service, providing a detailed analysis of its role within the broader regulatory landscape.

## Identifying the Legislative Basis of the Tuition Protection Service

Based on the provided information, the Tuition Protection Service is primarily outlined in **The ESOS Act 2000**.

### The Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000

The Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000 is the cornerstone of the regulatory framework governing the delivery of education to international students in Australia ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)). The ESOS Act and related legislation are designed to protect the interests of international students who come to Australia on student visas ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

The ESOS Act 2000 explicitly outlines the tuition protection obligations of education providers and the activities of the TPS ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)). It ensures that training providers meet nationally consistent standards in education delivery, facilities, and services ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)). Breaches of the ESOS Act are treated seriously, with significant penalties ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework)).

### Key Functions of the ESOS Act 2000

The ESOS Act 2000 governs several critical aspects of international education in Australia, including:

1.  **Registration Process and Obligations of Registered Providers:** The ESOS Act sets out the requirements for education providers to be registered and the obligations they must meet to maintain their registration ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).
2.  **Tuition Protection Service (TPS):** The Act establishes and regulates the TPS, which provides tuition and financial assurance to international students ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).
3.  **Enforcement and Compliance Powers:** The ESOS Act grants the government the authority to enforce compliance with its provisions and to impose penalties for non-compliance ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).

### The Tuition Protection Service (TPS)

The Tuition Protection Service (TPS) is an Australian Government initiative designed to assist international students on student visas when their education providers are unable to fully deliver their course of study ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-students)). The TPS ensures that students receive the tuition they have paid for or, as a last resort, a refund ([uts.edu.au](https://www.uts.edu.au/current-students/info-international-students/your-rights-and-responsibilities/tuition-protection-service)).

The TPS was established in 2012 as an international student tuition protection scheme under the ESOS Act 2000 ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)). It was later expanded to include specific domestic student cohorts under the VET Student Loans Act 2016, the Higher Education Support Act 2003, and the Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency Act 2011 ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)).

### How the TPS Works

The TPS operates by ensuring that if a provider defaults, they have a legal obligation to either arrange for students to continue their studies at an alternative provider or provide students with a refund of unspent tuition fees ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)). The TPS is sector-funded, with providers contributing an annual levy calculated based on the size and risk of default ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)). These levies fund the placement and refund activities ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).

### Provider and Student Defaults

Under the ESOS Act, a registered provider defaults if they fail to start providing the course to the student, cease providing the course after it has started, or refuse to provide the course due to the student's failure to pay, breach of visa conditions, or misbehavior ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).

An overseas student defaults if they do not start the course on the agreed starting day, withdraw from the course, or the provider refuses to continue providing the course due to the student's actions ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).

### Provider Obligations Following a Default

Following a provider default, the provider must:

*   Give written notice of the default to the relevant ESOS agency and the TPS Director within 3 business days ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).
*   Give written notice of the default to the affected students ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).
*   Discharge its obligations to students within 14 days by either arranging for a place in an alternative course or providing a refund of unspent tuition fees ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).
*   Notify the relevant ESOS agency and the TPS Director of the outcome of the discharge of obligations within 7 days after the end of the provider obligation period ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).

### Student Obligations Following a Default

Following a student default, the provider must fulfill its obligations under sections 47A-47H of the ESOS Act, which include providing a refund to the defaulted student within 4 weeks and notifying the relevant ESOS agency and the TPS Director if a refund was provided under section 47E of the ESOS Act ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/international-providers-tps)).

### Amendments to the ESOS Act

The ESOS Act has been amended several times to enhance its effectiveness and address emerging issues in the international education sector. Notable amendments include:

*   **Education Services for Overseas Students Legislation Amendment (Tuition Protection Service and Other Measures) Act 2012:** This amendment established the Tuition Protection Service and introduced other measures to strengthen the protection of international students ([legislation.gov.au](https://www.legislation.gov.au/C2012A00009/latest), [aph.gov.au](https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Bills_Legislation/Bills_Search_Results/Result?bId=r4675)).
*   **Education Services for Overseas Students Amendment (Re-registration of Providers and Other Measures) Act 2010:** This amendment introduced a risk-managed re-registration process for education providers and new registration requirements ([internationaleducation.gov.au](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/ESOS-Act/Pages/default.aspx)).

### Other Relevant Legislation

While the ESOS Act 2000 is the primary legislation outlining the TPS, other acts also play a role in the broader tuition protection framework. These include:

*   **VET Student Loans Act 2016:** This act extends tuition protection to domestic Vocational Education and Training (VET) students receiving VET Student Loan (VSL) assistance ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)).
*   **Higher Education Support Act 2003:** This act provides tuition protection for domestic higher education students receiving FEE-HELP or HECS-HELP loan assistance ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)).
*   **Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency Act 2011:** This act further supports tuition protection for specific domestic student cohorts ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)).

### The Role of the TPS Director and Advisory Board

The TPS is managed by the TPS Director, a statutory position created under Commonwealth legislation ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)). The TPS Director is responsible for the delivery and maintenance of the long-term sustainability of the Service ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)).

The TPS Director is supported by the TPS Advisory Board, which consists of Commonwealth and independent members ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)). The Board provides advice and makes recommendations to the TPS Director on the settings of the TPS levies ([education.gov.au](https://www.education.gov.au/tps/about-tuition-protection-services-tps)).

### Conclusion

In conclusion, the Tuition Protection Service is primarily outlined in the **Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act 2000**. This Act establishes the legal framework for the delivery of quality education to international students in Australia and provides tuition and financial assurance through the TPS. While other legislation, such as the VET Student Loans Act 2016 and the Higher Education Support Act 2003, extends tuition protection to domestic student cohorts, the ESOS Act 2000 remains the foundational legislation for the protection of international students' tuition fees. The ESOS Act 2000 ensures that international students receive the education they have paid for or, as a last resort, a refund, thereby safeguarding Australia's reputation as a provider of quality education.

## References
