question_results.question:
Which of the following is a place that a student may apply for a student visa:

Answer options:
Office of Fair Trading
English Australia
At an AEI office
Online through the DHA website
correct_answers: Online through the DHA website
extracted_answers: Online through the DHA website
question_results.full_response:
## Applying for an Australian Student Visa: A Detailed Guide to Online Applications

The pursuit of international education in Australia necessitates a thorough understanding of the student visa application process. As of 2025, Australia has implemented updated regulations to streamline the visa process and ensure the integrity of its international education system ([Srivastava, 2025](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/australias-updated-student-visa-rules-2025-key-you-know-srivastava-qtylc)). Among the provided options, the correct answer is that students may apply for a student visa **online through the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) website**. This report will provide a comprehensive overview of the Australian student visa application process, focusing on the online application method, recent changes, and essential requirements for prospective international students.

### The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) as the Primary Application Portal

The Australian Department of Home Affairs (DHA) is the official government body responsible for immigration and visa matters. The DHA website serves as the primary portal for all visa applications, including the Student Visa (Subclass 500) ([Study Australia, n.d.a](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/student-visa-subclass-500)). The online application process through the DHA website, specifically via ImmiAccount, is the standard and most efficient method for lodging a student visa application ([MSM Unify, n.d.](https://www.msmunify.com/study-in-australia/student-visa/)).

### Why the Other Options Are Incorrect

*   **Office of Fair Trading:** The Office of Fair Trading is typically responsible for consumer protection and business regulations, not immigration matters.
*   **English Australia:** English Australia is a peak body for English language colleges. While they provide information and resources for students studying English in Australia, they are not involved in visa processing.
*   **At an AEI office:** While education agents can assist with the visa application process, the application itself is lodged online through the DHA, not directly at an agent's office ([Study Australia, n.d.b](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/visa-application-process)).

### The Online Application Process Through ImmiAccount

The online application process involves several key steps:

1.  **Creating an ImmiAccount:** The first step is to create an account on the DHA's online portal, ImmiAccount ([MSM Unify, n.d.](https://www.msmunify.com/study-in-australia/student-visa/)). This account will be used to complete the application form, upload supporting documents, pay the visa application fee, and track the application status.
2.  **Completing the Application Form:** The Student Visa (Subclass 500) application form must be filled out online with accurate and consistent information ([Immigration News Australia, n.d.](https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-student-visa-500-a-2025-guide-for-international-students/)). The form requires detailed personal information, educational background, work experience, and reasons for choosing to study in Australia.
3.  **Gathering and Uploading Supporting Documents:** A range of supporting documents must be gathered and uploaded to the ImmiAccount ([Oz Studies, n.d.](https://www.ozstudies.com/studying-in-australia/how-to-study-in-australia/how-to-apply-for-student-visa-complete-guide)). These documents typically include:

    *   **Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE):** A mandatory document confirming acceptance into an Australian educational institution ([Admission AC Blog, n.d.](https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/05/australia-changes-rules-for-student-visas-check-new-requirement-for-a-student-visa-application/)).
    *   **Passport:** A valid passport with sufficient validity for the duration of the intended stay.
    *   **Proof of English Proficiency:** Results from an approved English language test, such as IELTS, TOEFL, or PTE Academic ([Study Australia, n.d.b](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/visa-application-process)).
    *   **Proof of Financial Capacity:** Evidence of sufficient funds to cover tuition fees, living expenses, and travel costs ([Study Australia, n.d.b](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/visa-application-process)).
    *   **Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC):** Proof of OSHC for the duration of the stay ([Study Australia, n.d.b](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/visa-application-process)).
    *   **Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) Statement:** A statement explaining the applicant's reasons for studying in Australia and their intentions to return home after completing their studies ([Oz Studies, n.d.](https://www.ozstudies.com/studying-in-australia/how-to-study-in-australia/how-to-apply-for-student-visa-complete-guide)).
    *   **Academic Transcripts and Certificates:** Evidence of previous educational qualifications.
    *   **Police Clearance Certificate:** If required, a police clearance certificate from the applicant's home country.
4.  **Paying the Visa Application Fee:** The visa application fee, which is currently AUD $710 for the main applicant, must be paid online through ImmiAccount ([Immigration News Australia, n.d.](https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-student-visa-500-a-2025-guide-for-international-students/)). Additional charges apply for dependents.
5.  **Submitting the Application:** Once the application form is completed and all supporting documents are uploaded, the application can be submitted online through ImmiAccount ([MSM Unify, n.d.](https://www.msmunify.com/study-in-australia/student-visa/)). A Transaction Reference Number (TRN) will be issued to track the application status.
6.  **Attending a Biometric Appointment (If Required):** In some cases, applicants may be required to provide biometric information at an Australian visa application center ([MSM Unify, n.d.](https://www.msmunify.com/study-in-australia/student-visa/)).
7.  **Awaiting the Visa Decision:** The processing time for Australian student visas varies, but it typically ranges from 1 to 4 months ([Immigration News Australia, n.d.](https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-student-visa-500-a-2025-guide-for-international-students/)). The application status can be tracked through ImmiAccount.

### Key Changes to the Student Visa Process in 2025

Several key changes have been implemented in the Australian student visa process for 2025:

*   **Mandatory Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE):** As of January 1, 2025, all student visa applications must include a CoE from an Australian educational institution ([Admission AC Blog, n.d.](https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/05/australia-changes-rules-for-student-visas-check-new-requirement-for-a-student-visa-application/)). Letters of Offer are no longer accepted as proof of admission.
*   **Enrollment Caps:** A National Planning Level (NPL) cap of 270,000 new international student commencements has been introduced for 2025 ([Visa and Immigrations, n.d.](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)). This cap aims to manage the growth of the international student population and ensure infrastructure and economic sustainability.
*   **Prioritized Visa Processing:** Applications for courses in healthcare, engineering, and IT will receive priority processing ([College Dunia, n.d.](https://collegedunia.com/australia/article/australia-student-visa-new-policies)).
*   **Simplified Documentation:** Students meeting specific eligibility criteria may require fewer documents for their visa applications ([College Dunia, n.d.](https://collegedunia.com/australia/article/australia-student-visa-new-policies)).

### The Importance of the Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE)

The CoE is a critical document that confirms a student's acceptance into an Australian university, including details about their course, tuition fees, and program duration ([Visa and Immigrations, n.d.](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)). Without a CoE, a student visa application will be deemed invalid and cannot be processed ([Admission AC Blog, n.d.](https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/05/australia-changes-rules-for-student-visas-check-new-requirement-for-a-student-visa-application/)). To obtain a CoE, applicants must secure admission, pay tuition fees, and receive the CoE before lodging their visa applications.

### Visa Conditions and Compliance

While holding a Student Visa, students must comply with certain conditions, including:

*   Maintaining enrollment in a registered course ([Immigration News Australia, n.d.](https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-student-visa-500-a-2025-guide-for-international-students/)).
*   Attending classes regularly.
*   Working within the allowed hours (usually up to 40 hours per fortnight) ([Oz Studies, n.d.](https://www.ozstudies.com/studying-in-australia/how-to-study-in-australia/how-to-apply-for-student-visa-complete-guide)).
*   Maintaining OSHC.
*   Informing the institution of any address changes ([Oz Studies, n.d.](https://www.ozstudies.com/studying-in-australia/how-to-study-in-australia/how-to-apply-for-student-visa-complete-guide)).

### Seeking Assistance with the Visa Application

While it is possible to lodge a student visa application independently, seeking assistance from a registered migration agent or education agent can be beneficial ([Study Australia, n.d.b](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/visa-application-process)). These professionals can provide guidance on the application process, ensure that all required documents are submitted correctly, and assist with any complex issues that may arise.

### Conclusion

In conclusion, the primary method for applying for an Australian student visa is online through the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) website, utilizing the ImmiAccount portal. The updated regulations for 2025 emphasize the importance of the Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) and introduce enrollment caps to manage the growth of the international student population. Prospective students should familiarize themselves with the online application process, gather all required documents, and comply with the visa conditions to ensure a smooth and successful study experience in Australia.

### References

Admission AC Blog. (n.d.). Australia changes rules for student visas: Check new requirement for a student visa application. [https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/05/australia-changes-rules-for-student-visas-check-new-requirement-for-a-student-visa-application/](https://blog.admission.ac/2025/01/05/australia-changes-rules-for-student-visas-check-new-requirement-for-a-student-visa-application/)

College Dunia. (n.d.). Australia student visa new policies for 2025: A guide for Indian students. [https://collegedunia.com/australia/article/australia-student-visa-new-policies](https://collegedunia.com/australia/article/australia-student-visa-new-policies)

Immigration News Australia. (n.d.). Australian student visa 500 - A 2025 guide for international students. [https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-student-visa-500-a-2025-guide-for-international-students/](https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-student-visa-500-a-2025-guide-for-international-students/)

MSM Unify. (n.d.). Australia student visa in 2025 | Requirements, process and fees. [https://www.msmunify.com/study-in-australia/student-visa/](https://www.msmunify.com/study-in-australia/student-visa/)

Oz Studies. (n.d.). Applying for student visa in Australia: A step by step guide | Study in Australia. [https://www.ozstudies.com/studying-in-australia/how-to-study-in-australia/how-to-apply-for-student-visa-complete-guide](https://www.ozstudies.com/studying-in-australia/how-to-study-in-australia/how-to-apply-for-student-visa-complete-guide)

Srivastava, M. (2025, January 24). Australia’s updated student visa rules for 2025: Key changes you should know. LinkedIn. [https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/australias-updated-student-visa-rules-2025-key-you-know-srivastava-qtylc](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/australias-updated-student-visa-rules-2025-key-you-know-srivastava-qtylc)

question_results.question:
Which of the following is never required by DHA for an individual to obtain a student visa:

Answer options:
A valid passport
Providing appropriate information about the financial ability to pay for their study
Providing appropriate information about the English proficiency of the student
Providing appropriate information about the individuals knowledge of the history, language and culture of Australia.
correct_answers: Providing appropriate information about the individuals knowledge of the history, language and culture of Australia.
extracted_answers: Providing appropriate information about the individuals knowledge of the history, language and culture of Australia.
question_results.full_response:
## Determining Requirements for an Australian Student Visa: A Detailed Analysis

The query asks which of the listed items is *never* required by the Department of Home Affairs (DHA) for an individual to obtain an Australian student visa. Based on the provided information, the answer is: Providing appropriate information about the individual's knowledge of the history, language, and culture of Australia.

This report will delve into the requirements for obtaining an Australian student visa, focusing on the necessity of a valid passport, financial capacity, English proficiency, and the lack of requirement for demonstrating knowledge of Australian history, language, and culture.

### Core Requirements for an Australian Student Visa

To successfully apply for an Australian student visa (Subclass 500), international students must meet several key criteria set by the DHA. These requirements are designed to ensure that applicants are genuine students who have the financial means and academic ability to succeed in their chosen course of study ([visaverge.com](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).

#### 1. Valid Passport

A valid passport is a fundamental requirement for any international travel, including studying in Australia. The passport must be valid for the duration of the student's intended stay in Australia ([aeccglobal.com.np](https://www.aeccglobal.com.np/blog/australia-student-visa-requirements)). Without a valid passport, the visa application cannot proceed.

#### 2. Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE)

Since January 1, 2025, a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) is mandatory for all student visa applications ([visaandimmigrations.com](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)). The CoE is an official document issued by the educational institution, confirming the student's acceptance into a registered course. This requirement replaced the previous acceptance of Letters of Offer for onshore applications, ensuring that only students who have formally enrolled in a course can apply for a visa ([getgis.org](https://getgis.org/news/new-requirements-for-australia-student-visa-from-january-2025)).

#### 3. Genuine Student (GS) Requirement

The Genuine Student (GS) requirement, which replaced the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement on March 23, 2024, assesses the applicant's intention to study in Australia ([kangarooedu.au](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)). Applicants must answer targeted questions about their study plans, circumstances, and reasons for choosing to study in Australia. This ensures that the primary purpose of the visa is for education and not for other motives, such as seeking employment or permanent residency ([eia.edu.au](https://eia.edu.au/blog/recent-changes-on-australian-migration-strategy-and-student-visas-requirements/)).

#### 4. Financial Capacity

Applicants must demonstrate they have sufficient funds to cover tuition fees, living expenses, and travel costs for themselves and any accompanying family members ([studygurus.com.au](https://studygurus.com.au/minimum-financial-evidence-for-your-student-visa-in-australia/)). As of 2024, a single student must show available funds of at least AUD 29,710 for living expenses ([studygurus.com.au](https://studygurus.com.au/minimum-financial-evidence-for-your-student-visa-in-australia/)). This amount increases if a partner (additional AUD 10,394) or children (additional AUD 4,449 per child) are included in the application ([studygurus.com.au](https://studygurus.com.au/minimum-financial-evidence-for-your-student-visa-in-australia/)). Acceptable proof of funds includes bank statements, education loans, scholarships, and fixed deposits ([kangarooedu.au](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)). The DHA also considers the annual income of parents or partners, requiring a minimum annual income of AUD 87,856 for single applicants and AUD 102,500 if family members are included ([visaenvoy.com](https://visaenvoy.com/acceptable-source-of-funds-for-student-visa-australia/)).

#### 5. English Language Proficiency

Demonstrating English language proficiency is a critical requirement for non-native English speakers ([visaverge.com](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/english-language-requirements-for-australian-student-visa-ielts-score-and-visa-regulations/)). The DHA accepts several English language tests, including IELTS, TOEFL, PTE Academic, and Cambridge Advanced English (CAE) ([help.visaalliance.com](https://help.visaalliance.com/support/solutions/articles/51000429104-demonstrating-english-proficiency-for-studying-in-australia)). As of March 23, 2024, the minimum required scores for the Student Visa (Subclass 500) are:

*   IELTS: Overall 6.0 ([intlstudents.com.au](https://intlstudents.com.au/updates-to-english-language-requirements-for-subclass-500-student-visas/))
*   PTE: Overall 50 ([intlstudents.com.au](https://intlstudents.com.au/updates-to-english-language-requirements-for-subclass-500-student-visas/))
*   OET: B in each module ([intlstudents.com.au](https://intlstudents.com.au/updates-to-english-language-requirements-for-subclass-500-student-visas/))
*   TOEFL: Overall 64 ([intlstudents.com.au](https://intlstudents.com.au/updates-to-english-language-requirements-for-subclass-500-student-visas/))
*   CAE: Overall 169 ([intlstudents.com.au](https://intlstudents.com.au/updates-to-english-language-requirements-for-subclass-500-student-visas/))

Exemptions to the English language requirement apply to passport holders from Canada, New Zealand, the Republic of Ireland, the United Kingdom, and the United States of America ([intlstudents.com.au](https://intlstudents.com.au/updates-to-english-language-requirements-for-subclass-500-student-visas/)).

### Non-Requirement: Knowledge of Australian History, Language, and Culture

While the DHA mandates proof of English proficiency to ensure students can participate in academic life and integrate into the community, there is no requirement to demonstrate specific knowledge of Australian history, language (beyond English proficiency), or culture ([visaverge.com](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/english-language-requirements-for-australian-student-visa-ielts-score-and-visa-regulations/)). The focus is on the student's ability to study effectively in English and their genuine intention to pursue education in Australia.

### Rationale for Requirements

The Australian government's focus on financial capacity and English proficiency is driven by several factors:

*   **Economic Stability:** Ensuring students have sufficient funds prevents them from becoming a financial burden on the Australian community ([studygurus.com.au](https://studygurus.com.au/minimum-financial-evidence-for-your-student-visa-in-australia/)).
*   **Academic Success:** English proficiency is crucial for students to understand lectures, participate in discussions, and complete assignments successfully ([studyaustralia.gov.au](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/tools-and-resources/news/english-language-requirements-changes)).
*   **Visa Integrity:** The Genuine Student requirement aims to prevent visa fraud and ensure that students are coming to Australia for legitimate educational purposes ([eia.edu.au](https://eia.edu.au/blog/recent-changes-on-australian-migration-strategy-and-student-visas-requirements/)).

### Conclusion

In conclusion, while a valid passport, proof of financial capacity, and evidence of English proficiency are essential requirements for obtaining an Australian student visa, demonstrating knowledge of Australian history, language, and culture is not. The DHA prioritizes the student's ability to financially support themselves and succeed academically in an English-speaking environment. Therefore, the correct answer to the query is that providing information about an individual's knowledge of the history, language, and culture of Australia is *never* required by the DHA for a student visa application.

### References

aeccglobal.com.np. (2024, May 24). Australia Student Visa Requirements | Documents Checklist & more. AECC Nepal. [https://www.aeccglobal.com.np/blog/australia-student-visa-requirements](https://www.aeccglobal.com.np/blog/australia-student-visa-requirements)

question_results.question:
DHA considers evidentiary requirements for students from different countries on the basis of:

Answer options:
How many friends and relatives a student has who are currently living or studying in Australia.
How much business in trade and exports Australia does with the student’s country.
Statistical evidence of how students from that country comply with their visa conditions based on previous students’ behaviour in the last 12 months.
How likely it is that students will want to live in Australia after they graduate.
correct_answers: Statistical evidence of how students from that country comply with their visa conditions based on previous students’ behaviour in the last 12 months.

question_results.full_response:
## Determining Evidentiary Requirements for Australian Student Visas: A Risk-Based Approach

The Australian Department of Home Affairs (DHA) employs a risk-based framework to determine the evidentiary requirements for student visa applicants. This framework, known as the Simplified Student Visa Framework (SSVF), considers the immigration risk associated with both the student's country of citizenship and their chosen education provider. Rather than relying on subjective factors like the number of relatives in Australia or trade relationships, the DHA assesses risk based on statistical evidence of past student behavior and compliance with visa conditions ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/)). This report will delve into the specifics of this risk assessment, its implications, and the recent updates to the framework.

### The Simplified Student Visa Framework (SSVF) and Risk Assessment

The SSVF, introduced in 2016, aims to streamline the student visa application process while maintaining the integrity of the system ([Australia Study, n.d.a](https://australiastudy.com/how-australias-new-risk-assessment-impacts-you/); [APH, n.d.a](https://www.aph.gov.au/About_Parliament/Parliamentary_departments/Parliamentary_Library/Research/Quick_Guides/2020-21/OverseasStudents)). Under the SSVF, the level of evidence required from a student applicant is determined by a combination of the immigration risk rating of their country of citizenship and the risk rating of their education provider ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/)).

The DHA uses immigration risk methodology to calculate evidence levels for each education provider and country ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/)). This methodology considers several key indicators, each weighted to reflect its relative importance in assessing risk ([Monitor ICEF, 2024](https://monitor.icef.com/2024/02/australian-unis-brace-for-risk-assessment-as-visa-rejections-continue/)):

*   **Rate of refusals due to fraud:** This indicator carries the highest weighting (40%), highlighting the DHA's focus on detecting and preventing fraudulent applications ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/); [Monitor ICEF, 2024](https://monitor.icef.com/2024/02/australian-unis-brace-for-risk-assessment-as-visa-rejections-continue/)).
*   **Rate of refusals (excluding fraud):** This accounts for 10% of the weighting. It captures instances where applications are rejected for reasons other than fraud, such as failing to meet financial or English language requirements ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/); [Monitor ICEF, 2024](https://monitor.icef.com/2024/02/australian-unis-brace-for-risk-assessment-as-visa-rejections-continue/)).
*   **Rate of student visa holders becoming unlawful non-citizens:** This indicator, weighted at 15%, reflects the risk of students overstaying their visas and remaining in Australia illegally ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/); [Monitor ICEF, 2024](https://monitor.icef.com/2024/02/australian-unis-brace-for-risk-assessment-as-visa-rejections-continue/)).
*   **Rate of Subsequent Protection Visa applications:** This accounts for 10% of the weighting. It measures the tendency of student visa holders to apply for protection visas after arriving in Australia, which can be an indicator of using the student visa program for purposes other than genuine study ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/); [Monitor ICEF, 2024](https://monitor.icef.com/2024/02/australian-unis-brace-for-risk-assessment-as-visa-rejections-continue/)).
*   **Rate of visa cancellations:** This is weighted at 25% ([Monitor ICEF, 2024](https://monitor.icef.com/2024/02/australian-unis-brace-for-risk-assessment-as-visa-rejections-continue/)).

Based on these indicators, countries and education providers are assigned an evidence level. Higher evidence levels indicate a higher risk rating and necessitate more extensive documentation from student visa applicants ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/)). This typically includes providing evidence of financial capacity and English language proficiency ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/)).

### Impact of Risk Levels on Student Visa Applications

The combined immigration risk of the student's country and education provider directly impacts the documentation required for their visa application ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/)). Students from low-risk countries enrolling in low-risk education providers generally face fewer documentation requirements ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/)). However, students from high-risk countries must provide more extensive documentation, regardless of their education provider's risk level ([Education One, n.d.a](https://www.educationone.net.au/tips-tricks/country-risk-level-explained/)). This may include demonstrating financial capacity to cover tuition, living expenses, and travel costs, as well as providing evidence of English language proficiency through standardized tests like IELTS or TOEFL ([Visa Envoy, n.d.a](https://visaenvoy.com/risk-level-changes-to-student-visas/); [Studies Overseas, n.d.a](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).

### Recent Updates and Trends in Risk Levels

The DHA regularly reviews and updates the risk levels assigned to countries and education providers ([CAQA, n.d.a](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/australia-s-new-risk-levels-implications-for-international-students-and-education-providers)). These updates are based on the latest immigration data and aim to ensure the framework remains responsive to changing trends and risks ([ImmiNews, 2024](https://imminews.com.au/student-visa-trends-for-2024-25-key-updates-and-whats-ahead)). For instance, in November 2024, the DHA implemented an update to the evidence levels based on immigration data from October 1, 2023, to September 30, 2024 ([ImmiNews, 2024](https://imminews.com.au/student-visa-trends-for-2024-25-key-updates-and-whats-ahead)).

Recent changes have seen some countries reclassified into different risk levels. For example, Colombia, Brazil, Ecuador, Hungary, the Philippines, Indonesia, Taiwan, and South Africa are now considered low-risk countries, meaning students from these nations may not need to provide as much financial or English language evidence unless specifically requested ([Visa Envoy, n.d.a](https://visaenvoy.com/risk-level-changes-to-student-visas/)). Conversely, India, Pakistan, and Nepal have been identified as higher-risk countries, requiring students from these nations to provide more comprehensive documentation ([Visa Envoy, n.d.a](https://visaenvoy.com/risk-level-changes-to-student-visas/)).

These changes reflect the DHA's ongoing efforts to refine its risk assessment and target resources towards areas of higher risk. The dynamic nature of the risk levels underscores the importance for prospective students to stay informed about the latest requirements and prepare their visa applications accordingly ([CAQA, n.d.a](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/australia-s-new-risk-levels-implications-for-international-students-and-education-providers)).

### Factors Influencing Visa Rejections

Understanding the reasons behind student visa rejections is crucial for applicants seeking to avoid potential pitfalls. Common reasons for rejection include ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)):

*   **Incomplete or incorrect documentation:** Providing all required documents with accuracy is paramount ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).
*   **Insufficient proof of funds:** Applicants must demonstrate they have sufficient funds to cover all expenses without relying on employment in Australia ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).
*   **Breach of the Genuine Student (GS) requirement:** Applicants must convince the DHA that their primary intention is to study in Australia temporarily ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).
*   **Unfulfilled English language proficiency condition:** Meeting the required English language standards is essential ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).*   **Poor academic performance:** A history of poor academic performance can raise concerns about the applicant's ability to succeed in their studies ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).
*   **Applying to low-ranked universities:** The DHA may scrutinize applications to less reputable institutions more closely ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).
*   **False or misleading information:** Providing false information can lead to visa rejection and a potential ban on future applications ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).
*   **Previous visa history:** A history of visa rejections or violations can negatively impact the current application ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).
*   **Course relevance:** The intended course of study must be relevant to the applicant's previous education or work experience ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).
*   **Failure to meet specific visa conditions:** Each visa subclass has specific conditions that must be met ([Studies Overseas, n.d.b](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).

### Strategies to Mitigate Risk and Avoid Visa Rejection

To increase the chances of a successful student visa application, applicants should consider the following strategies ([Studies Overseas, n.d.c](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)):

*   **Demonstrate clear intentions for study:** Clearly articulate the reasons for choosing the course, the preference for studying in Australia, and the intention to return home after completion ([Studies Overseas, n.d.c](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).*   **Provide detailed answers to Genuine Student (GS) questions:** Convincingly demonstrate the intention to stay in Australia temporarily for study purposes ([Studies Overseas, n.d.c](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).
*   **Meet English language proficiency requirements:** Prepare thoroughly for English language tests and achieve the necessary scores ([Studies Overseas, n.d.c](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).*   **Discuss personal circumstances to return home:** Provide a comprehensive view of personal circumstances, including family responsibilities, economic conditions, and long-term career goals ([Studies Overseas, n.d.c](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).
*   **Ensure honesty and accuracy:** Double-check all information and documents to ensure they are truthful and complete ([Studies Overseas, n.d.c](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/top-reasons-for-australia-student-visa-rejection)).

### Conclusion

The DHA's approach to determining evidentiary requirements for student visas is firmly rooted in statistical evidence and risk assessment. By analyzing past student behavior and compliance with visa conditions, the DHA aims to identify and mitigate potential risks to the integrity of the student visa program. While factors like personal connections or trade relationships do not directly influence the assessment, the DHA's focus remains on ensuring that genuine students with the financial capacity and academic intentions are able to pursue their studies in Australia. As the risk levels are subject to change, prospective students should stay informed about the latest requirements and prepare their visa applications meticulously to maximize their chances of success.

question_results.question:
A student you recruited to study in Australia is studying a Bachelor of Engineering at university on a Student Visa. The student is finding their study program very difficult and would like to study part- time rather than full-time. The student can:

Answer options:
Study part-time under The National Code as it allows students to study part-time in exceptional circumstances.
Not change to part-time study. Under The National Code students on student visa are not allowed to study part-time.
Study part-time if the Vice-Chancellor of the university approves their study plan.
Not study part-time because the Vice-Chancellor of their university does not allow students to study part-time.
correct_answers: Not change to part-time study. Under The National Code students on student visa are not allowed to study part-time.
extracted_answers: Study part-time under The National Code as it allows students to study part-time in exceptional circumstances.
question_results.full_response:
# Report on Part-Time Study Options for International Students on Student Visas in AustraliaThe following report addresses the query regarding whether an international student studying a Bachelor of Engineering on a Student Visa in Australia can change from full-time to part-time study. The report will analyze relevant regulations, specifically focusing on the National Code 2018, and provide a well-supported conclusion.

## Analysis of the National Code 2018 and Student Visa Regulations

The primary legislation governing the provision of education to international students in Australia is the *Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act* and the associated *National Code of Practice for Registration Authorities and Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018* ([UNE](https://www.une.edu.au/study/international/visa-and-fees/rules-and-obligations)). The National Code sets standards for registered providers of education to overseas students, ensuring the quality of education and the well-being of international students.

A key requirement for international students on a student visa is to maintain satisfactory academic progress and adhere to visa conditions. One of these conditions typically involves enrolling in a full-time study load to complete the course within the expected duration, as stated on the Electronic Confirmation of Enrolment (eCoE) ([UNE](https://www.une.edu.au/study/international/visa-and-fees/rules-and-obligations)).

However, the National Code recognizes that exceptional circumstances may arise that prevent a student from maintaining a full-time study load. Standard 13 of the National Code addresses deferment, suspension, or cancellation of study during enrolment and acknowledges the possibility of compassionate or compelling circumstances ([International Education](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD13.aspx)).

### Compassionate and Compelling Circumstances

Compassionate or compelling circumstances are generally defined as those beyond the student's control that affect their course progress or well-being ([International Education](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD13.aspx)). Examples of such circumstances include:

*   Serious illness or injury, supported by a medical certificate ([International Education](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD13.aspx)).
*   Death of a close family member ([International Education](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD13.aspx)).
*   Major political upheaval or natural disaster in the student's home country requiring emergency travel ([Ask VU](https://askvu.vu.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/77/~/what-are-exceptional,-compassionate-or-compelling-circumstances?)).
*   A traumatic experience, such as involvement in a serious accident or being a victim of a serious crime ([International Education](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD13.aspx)).
*   Inability to begin study on the agreed starting date due to a delay in receiving an international student visa beyond their control ([Ask VU](https://askvu.vu.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/77/~/what-are-exceptional,-compassionate-or-compelling-circumstances?)).
*   The registered provider was unable to offer a pre-requisite unit ([International Education](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD13.aspx)).

If such circumstances exist, the education provider may allow the student to:

*   Take an intermission from formal study for up to 12 months ([Ask VU](https://askvu.vu.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/77/~/what-are-exceptional,-compassionate-or-compelling-circumstances?)).
*   Undertake a reduced study load in a compulsory semester of study ([Ask VU](https://askvu.vu.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/77/~/what-are-exceptional,-compassionate-or-compelling-circumstances?)).
*   Extend their Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) to complete their course ([Ask VU](https://askvu.vu.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/77/~/what-are-exceptional,-compassionate-or-compelling-circumstances?)).

It is crucial to note that circumstances within the student's control or expected in the normal course of study, work, family, or social life are generally *not* considered compassionate or compelling ([Ask VU](https://askvu.vu.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/77/~/what-are-exceptional,-compassionate-or-compelling-circumstances?)).

### Provider Responsibilities and Reporting

When a student requests a reduced study load or suspension of enrolment, the provider must inform the Department of Education through the Provider Registration and International Student Management System (PRISMS) ([International Education](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD13.aspx)). The Department of Home Affairs (formerly DIAC/DIBP) receives electronic notification of the change in enrolment status. The provider must also advise the student that changing their enrolment status may impact their student visa and suggest they contact the Department of Home Affairs to discuss their situation ([International Education](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD13.aspx)).

### Impact on Student Visa

If a student's course end date is affected by a suspension or reduced study load, they will likely need to apply for a new visa before their current visa expires ([International Education](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD13.aspx)). Failing to manage visa validity could result in removal from the country or other penalties ([Visa Verge](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).

## Engineering Studies in Australia

Australia is a popular destination for international students seeking engineering degrees ([Oz Studies](https://www.ozstudies.com/blog/study-australia/the-benefits-of-studying-engineering-in-australia)). Australian universities offer a wide range of engineering courses, including civil, mechanical, electrical, chemical, and aerospace engineering ([Oz Studies](https://www.ozstudies.com/blog/study-australia/the-benefits-of-studying-engineering-in-australia)). Many courses are accredited by Engineers Australia, which is valuable for aspiring engineers ([Oz Studies](https://www.ozstudies.com/blog/study-australia/the-benefits-of-studying-engineering-in-australia)).

The cost of a Bachelor of Engineering degree in Australia typically ranges from $25,000 to $40,000 per year ([Overseas Students Australia](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/how-to-become-an-engineer-in-australia/)). International students can explore available financial aid programs and government scholarships to help offset these costs ([Overseas Students Australia](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/how-to-become-an-engineer-in-australia/)).

### Vice-Chancellor's International Scholarships Scheme

The University of Sydney, for example, offers the Vice-Chancellor's International Scholarships Scheme (VCIS) to attract and support high-achieving international students ([MSM Unify](https://www.msmunify.com/blogs/vice-chancellors-international-scholarships-scheme)). These scholarships provide financial assistance to lessen the financial strain on students ([MSM Unify](https://www.msmunify.com/blogs/vice-chancellors-international-scholarships-scheme)). The scholarship values vary, with some offering A$40,000 per year, A$20,000 per semester, A$10,000 per semester, or A$5,000 per semester ([MSM Unify](https://www.msmunify.com/blogs/vice-chancellors-international-scholarships-scheme)). However, recipients must maintain a minimum semester average mark (SAM) of 65 and have no outstanding fees to receive subsequent payments ([Sydney](https://www.sydney.edu.au/scholarships/e/vice-chancellor-international-scholarships-scheme.html)).

Macquarie University also offers a Vice-Chancellor's International Scholarship, which rewards academic excellence and attracts high-performing students ([Macquarie](https://www.mq.edu.au/study/admissions-and-entry/scholarships/international/vice-chancellor-s-international-scholarship)).

## Conclusion

Based on the analysis of the National Code 2018 and related regulations, the most accurate answer to the query is:

**Study part-time under The National Code as it allows students to study part-time in exceptional circumstances.**

While the general requirement is for international students to study full-time, the National Code recognizes that compassionate or compelling circumstances may warrant a reduced study load. The student's difficulty with the study program *could* potentially qualify as an exceptional circumstance, but this would need to be assessed and documented by the university according to their policies and procedures. The student would need to provide evidence to support their claim, and the university would need to determine if the circumstances meet the criteria for allowing a reduced study load. It is important to note that the university must report any change in enrolment status to the Department of Education and that the student's visa may be affected.

The other options are incorrect because:

*   The National Code *does* allow for part-time study in exceptional circumstances.
*   While the Vice-Chancellor's approval might be required as part of the university's internal processes, the ultimate decision is governed by the National Code and relevant visa regulations.
*   The Vice-Chancellor's personal preferences do not override the provisions of the National Code.

Therefore, the student *can* potentially change to part-time study, but only if they can demonstrate compassionate or compelling circumstances and the university approves their request in accordance with the National Code and relevant visa regulations.

question_results.question:
You recruited a student to study in a Foundation Year Program. The student has not been attending classes. The student is on a student visa and has been absent from class for two weeks now. The Institution should:

Answer options:
Let the student do what they want as they are in Australia and away from their parents.
Send an email to all agents telling them that the student you recruited is a very bad one.
Contact you immediately and ask for help in locating the student.
Report the student without seeking to find out where the student is.
correct_answers: Contact you immediately and ask for help in locating the student.
extracted_answers: Contact you immediately and ask for help in locating the student.
question_results.full_response:
Here is a detailed report addressing the scenario of an international student on a student visa who has been absent from a Foundation Year Program for two weeks, focusing on the institution's responsibilities and actions.

### Report: Institutional Response to Student Absence Under Australian Student Visa Regulations

**Introduction**

This report addresses the appropriate institutional response to a situation where an international student, holding a student visa and enrolled in a Foundation Year Program in Australia, has been absent from classes for two weeks. Given the stringent regulatory framework governing international student visas in Australia, the institution has specific obligations to ensure compliance with the *Education Services for Overseas Students (ESOS) Act* and the *National Code of Practice for Providers of Education and Training to Overseas Students 2018* (National Code) ([National Code](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD6.aspx)). Ignoring the student's absence or taking inappropriate actions could jeopardize the student's visa status and the institution's registration.

**Determining the Appropriate Institutional Response**

Based on the information provided, the only appropriate course of action for the institution is to contact the agent who recruited the student immediately and ask for help in locating the student. The other options are not only inappropriate but also potentially illegal and unethical.

**Detailed Analysis of Inappropriate Options**

1.  **"Let the student do what they want as they are in Australia and away from their parents."**

    This option reflects a complete disregard for the institution's duty of care and legal obligations. Under the ESOS framework, institutions have a responsibility to monitor student attendance and ensure they comply with their visa conditions ([National Code](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD6.aspx)). Ignoring the absence would be a direct violation of these responsibilities. Furthermore, it neglects the potential welfare issues the student might be facing.

2.  **"Send an email to all agents telling them that the student you recruited is a very bad one."**

    This action is unprofessional, unethical, and potentially defamatory. It violates the student's privacy and does not address the core issue of the student's well-being or visa compliance. Such communication could also damage the institution's relationship with its agents and harm its reputation ([National Code](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD6.aspx)).

3.  **"Report the student without seeking to find out where the student is."**

    While reporting the student might eventually be necessary, doing so without first attempting to locate the student and understand the reasons for their absence is premature and fails to meet the institution's obligations under the National Code. The National Code emphasizes proactive intervention and support for students at risk of breaching their visa conditions ([National Code](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD6.aspx)).

**The Correct Course of Action: Contacting the Agent**

Contacting the agent who recruited the student is a logical first step for several reasons:

*   **Potential Information Source:** The agent may have contact information or insights into the student's circumstances that the institution lacks.
*   **Family Contact:** The agent may be in contact with the student's family and can help facilitate communication and support.
*   **Cultural Sensitivity:** The agent, particularly if based in the student's home country, may have a better understanding of cultural factors influencing the student's behavior and can offer culturally sensitive support.**Detailed Steps the Institution Should Take**

Given the two-week absence, the institution should undertake the following steps promptly:

1.  **Review Attendance Records:** Verify the accuracy of the attendance records and confirm the duration of the absence.
2.  **Contact the Student:** Attempt to contact the student through all available channels, including phone, email, and any emergency contact information provided during enrollment.
3.  **Contact the Agent:** Reach out to the agent who recruited the student, explain the situation, and request their assistance in locating the student and understanding the reasons for the absence.
4.  **Internal Counseling:** Offer counseling services to the student to understand the challenges they are facing, whether academic, personal, or related to adapting to a new environment ([Overseas Students Australia](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
5.  **Formal Written Warning:** If contact is made, issue a formal written warning to the student, outlining the potential consequences of continued absence on their visa status.
6.  **Document All Actions:** Maintain a detailed record of all communication attempts, warnings, and support offered to the student.
7.  **Compliance Reporting:** If the student's attendance does not improve and the institution has exhausted all reasonable efforts to support them, consider reporting the student to the Department of Home Affairs for breaching visa conditions. This should be done in accordance with the institution's documented policies and procedures ([National Code](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD6.aspx)).

**Legal and Regulatory Context**

The Australian student visa program is governed by the *Migration Act 1958* and associated regulations. The *ESOS Act 2000* and the National Code provide a framework for ensuring the quality of education and welfare of international students. Key requirements include:

*   **Attendance Monitoring:** Providers must monitor student attendance and report students who fail to meet the minimum attendance requirements (typically 80% of scheduled course contact hours) ([National Code Part D, Standard 11](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD11.aspx)).
*   **Course Progress:** Providers must also monitor students' academic progress and provide support to those at risk of failing their courses ([National Code](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD6.aspx)).
*   **Notification of Intention to Report:** Before reporting a student for non-attendance or unsatisfactory course progress, providers must notify the student in writing of their intention to report and provide an opportunity for the student to access the provider's internal complaints and appeals process ([National Code Part D, Standard 11](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD11.aspx)).

**Impact of 2025 Visa Rule Changes**

As of 2025, several changes to the Australian student visa rules have come into effect, including:

*   **Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE):** A mandatory CoE is required for all visa applications, replacing Letters of Offer ([Visa Verge](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)). This underscores the importance of ensuring students are genuinely enrolled and attending their courses.
*   **Genuine Student (GS) Requirement:** The Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement has been replaced by the Genuine Student (GS) requirement, which involves targeted questions about the student's intention to study in Australia ([Kangaroo Edu](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)).
*   **Financial Capacity:** Increased scrutiny of financial capacity to cover living costs (approximately $21,041 per year as of 2025) and travel expenses ([Kangaroo Edu](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)).
*   **Work Rights:** Limitations on work rights during term time (up to 48 hours per fortnight) ([Kangaroo Edu](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)).

These changes emphasize the need for institutions to ensure that international students are genuine, committed to their studies, and have the resources to support themselves.

**Support Services for International Students**

Australian institutions are required to provide a range of support services to international students, including:

*   **Academic Support:** Learning and teaching centers, peer-assisted study sessions, and tutoring services ([Overseas Students Australia](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
*   **Counselling and Mental Health Services:** Support for personal, academic, and cultural adjustment issues ([Overseas Students Australia](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
*   **Language and Cultural Support:** English language classes, cultural orientation programs, and language exchange programs ([Overseas Students Australia](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
*   **Financial Aid and Scholarships:** Information and assistance with financial matters ([Overseas Students Australia](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
*   **Health and Wellness Services:** Access to healthcare and health-related information ([Overseas Students Australia](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)).

**Conclusion**In conclusion, the institution's immediate priority should be to contact the agent to help locate the student and understand the reasons for their absence. Following this, the institution must adhere to its documented policies and procedures for monitoring attendance, providing support, and, if necessary, reporting the student to the Department of Home Affairs. This approach ensures compliance with Australian student visa regulations and demonstrates a commitment to the welfare and success of international students. The changes to visa rules in 2025 further underscore the importance of proactive engagement and support for international students to ensure they remain compliant and successful in their studies.

***

**References**

Kangaroo Edu. (2025). *Navigating Australian Student Visa Requirements in 2025: A Beginner’s Guide*. [https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/)

National Code Part D, Standard 11. *National Code Part D, Standard 11*. [https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD11.aspx](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD11.aspx)

National Code. *National Code Part D, Standard 6*. [https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD6.aspx](https://internationaleducation.gov.au/Regulatory-Information/Education-Services-for-Overseas-Students-ESOS-Legislative-Framework/National-Code/nationalcodepartd/Pages/ExplanatoryguideD6.aspx)

Overseas Students Australia. *Support Services For International Students In Australia*. [https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/](https://overseasstudentsaustralia.com/support-services-for-international-students-in-australia/)

Visa Verge. (2025, February 18). *Australia Updates Student Visa Rules for 2025 to Ensure Genuine Applicants*. [https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)
