question_results.question:
One of the other counsellors in your office comes to ask your advice on the following situation:
A student will study in an ELICOS program for 6 months and then enter into a Masters of Biotechnology course. The student has paid her tuition fees and the Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) for the ELICOS course. She wants to pay her tuition fees for the Masters course but the university is asking her to also pay OSHC. The counsellor is unsure about what the student should do about their OSHC for the Masters course.
You advise the counsellor that the student:

Answer options:
needs to take out OSHC for the Masters course too before applying for a student visa as it is compulsory for international students to have health insurance for all courses in a package of offers while studying in Australia.
should take out OSHC covering the Masters course too because it is always a better option to be covered just in case of an accident.
does not need to pay OSHC to cover the length of the other course. This is just another expense in an already expensive process.
correct_answers: needs to take out OSHC for the Masters course too before applying for a student visa as it is compulsory for international students to have health insurance for all courses in a package of offers while studying in Australia.
extracted_answers: needs to take out OSHC for the Masters course too before applying for a student visa as it is compulsory for international students to have health insurance for all courses in a package of offers while studying in Australia.
question_results.full_response:
Here's a detailed report addressing the OSHC requirements for an international student progressing from an ELICOS program to a Masters course in Australia.

### Report: OSHC Requirements for International Students in Australia

**Introduction**

This report addresses the query regarding an international student in Australia who has completed an English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students (ELICOS) program and is about to commence a Masters of Biotechnology course. The student has already paid tuition fees and Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) for the ELICOS program but is now being asked by the university to pay OSHC for the Masters course as well. This report aims to provide clarity on whether the student is required to obtain additional OSHC coverage for the Masters program.

**Overview of OSHC**

Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) is a mandatory health insurance requirement for international students undertaking formal studies in Australia ([Study Australia](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc)). The Australian Department of Home Affairs requires that international students maintain OSHC for the duration of their stay in Australia on a student visa ([Department of Home Affairs](https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/)). This health cover ensures that students have access to medical and hospital services, contributing to their well-being and enabling them to focus on their academic pursuits ([UniCreds Blog](https://unicreds.com/blog/student-health-insurance-australia/)).

**Purpose of OSHC**

The primary purpose of OSHC is to provide international students with health insurance coverage similar to that available to Australian residents through Medicare. It helps cover the costs of medical treatments, hospital stays, ambulance services, and prescription medications ([OSHC Australia](https://oshcaustralia.com.au/en)). OSHC ensures that international students are not burdened with high medical expenses, which can be financially crippling ([AskP Study in Australia](https://www.askpstudyinaustralia.com/2019/09/what-is-overseas-student-health.html)).

**Coverage Details**

A basic OSHC plan typically covers:

*   Visits to a general practitioner (GP) ([Study Australia](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc)).
*   Some hospital treatments ([Study Australia](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc)).
*   Emergency ambulance services ([OSHC Australia](https://oshcaustralia.com.au/en)).
*   Limited pharmaceuticals (medicines) ([Study Australia](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc)).

However, OSHC may not cover treatments such as dental, optical, or physiotherapy, and students may need to purchase extras cover or private health insurance for these services ([Study Australia](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc)).

**ELICOS and OSHC**

ELICOS programs are designed to help international students improve their English language skills ([Leap Scholar](https://leapscholar.com/blog/all-about-elicos-australia-fees-courses-requirements/)). These courses are often a pathway to further academic studies in Australia. International students enrolled in ELICOS programs are also required to have OSHC ([KMH Consultancy](https://kmhconsultancy.com.au/elicos-admissions/)). The OSHC coverage for ELICOS students ensures they have access to medical care while improving their English proficiency.

**Analysis of the Student's Situation**

The student in question has completed a 6-month ELICOS program and has paid for OSHC coverage for that period. Now, as she transitions to a Masters of Biotechnology course, the university is requesting additional OSHC payment.

**Legal and Visa Requirements**

The Department of Home Affairs mandates that international students hold valid OSHC for the entire duration of their student visa ([Department of Home Affairs](https://www.homeaffairs.gov.au/)). If the student's visa is extended to cover the Masters course, she must also extend her OSHC to align with the new visa end date ([Budget Policy](https://budgetpolicy.com/blogs/detail/how-to-extend-your-oshc-policy-the-complete-guide-for-students-in-australia)). Failure to maintain continuous OSHC coverage can result in a breach of visa conditions, potentially leading to visa cancellation ([OSHC Australia](https://oshcaustralia.com.au/en/blog/renewing-your-oshc-policy)).

**Financial and Practical Considerations**

While it might seem like an additional expense, maintaining OSHC coverage is crucial for several reasons:

1.  **Visa Compliance:** As mentioned, it is a mandatory requirement for holding a student visa ([Maven Consulting Services](https://www.mavenconsultingservices.com/article/a-guide-to-oshc-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
2.  **Healthcare Access:** Without OSHC, international students may face significant out-of-pocket expenses for medical treatments ([Maven Consulting Services](https://www.mavenconsultingservices.com/article/a-guide-to-oshc-for-international-students-in-australia/)).
3.  **Peace of Mind:** Knowing that medical expenses are covered allows students to focus on their studies without the stress of potential healthcare costs ([UniCreds Blog](https://unicreds.com/blog/student-health-insurance-australia/)).

**Extending OSHC Coverage**

The student has several options for extending her OSHC coverage:

1.  **Contact Current Provider:** She can contact her current OSHC provider to extend her policy to cover the duration of the Masters course ([Budget Policy](https://budgetpolicy.com/blogs/detail/how-to-extend-your-oshc-policy-the-complete-guide-for-students-in-australia)).
2.  **Compare Providers:** She can compare different OSHC providers to find a plan that best suits her needs and budget ([OSHC Australia](https://oshcaustralia.com.au/en/blog/renewing-your-oshc-policy)).
3.  **University Assistance:** The university may offer assistance in arranging OSHC coverage ([AskP Study in Australia](https://www.askpstudyinaustralia.com/2019/09/what-is-overseas-student-health.html)).

**Recommendation**

Based on the information available, the most appropriate advice for the counsellor is that the student **needs to take out OSHC for the Masters course too before applying for a student visa as it is compulsory for international students to have health insurance for all courses in a package of offers while studying in Australia.** This is not merely a "better option" but a mandatory requirement to comply with visa regulations and ensure access to healthcare services.

**Conclusion**

In conclusion, while the additional cost of OSHC for the Masters course may seem burdensome, it is a necessary expense to comply with Australian visa requirements and ensure access to healthcare. The student should extend her OSHC coverage to align with the duration of her Masters program to avoid any potential visa issues and to protect her health and well-being.

**References**

*   AskP Study in Australia. (2019, September 6). What Is OSHC? How to meet this essential student visa requirement. [https://www.askpstudyinaustralia.com/2019/09/what-is-overseas-student-health.html](https://www.askpstudyinaustralia.com/2019/09/what-is-overseas-student-health.html)
*   Budget Policy. (2024, November 12). How to Extend Your OSHC Coverage for a Student Visa in Australia – Step-by-Step Guide. [https://budgetpolicy.com/blogs/detail/how-to-extend-your-oshc-policy-the-complete-guide-for-students-in-australia](https://budgetpolicy.com/blogs/detail/how-to-extend-your-oshc-policy-the-complete-guide-for-students-in-australia)
*   KMH Consultancy. ELICOS Admissions - Step-by-Step Guide to ELICOS Admissions Process. [https://kmhconsultancy.com.au/elicos-admissions/](https://kmhconsultancy.com.au/elicos-admissions/)
*   Leap Scholar. ELICOS in Australia: Fees, Courses & Requirements. [https://leapscholar.com/blog/all-about-elicos-australia-fees-courses-requirements/](https://leapscholar.com/blog/all-about-elicos-australia-fees-courses-requirements/)
*   Maven Consulting Services. (2023, November 25). OSHC Australia: Essential Health Cover for International Students. [https://www.mavenconsultingservices.com/article/a-guide-to-oshc-for-international-students-in-australia/](https://www.mavenconsultingservices.com/article/a-guide-to-oshc-for-international-students-in-australia/)
*   OSHC Australia. Renewing Your OSHC Policy For Students. [https://oshcaustralia.com.au/en/blog/renewing-your-oshc-policy](https://oshcaustralia.com.au/en/blog/renewing-your-oshc-policy)
*   OSHC Australia. Compare Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) - Study in Australia. [https://oshcaustralia.com.au/en](https://oshcaustralia.com.au/en)
*   Study Australia. Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC) | Study Australia. [https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/overseas-student-health-cover-oshc)
*   UniCreds Blog. (2023, August 17). Student Health Insurance Australia 2025 – Everything You Need to Know. [https://unicreds.com/blog/student-health-insurance-australia/](https://unicreds.com/blog/student-health-insurance-australia/)

question_results.question:
The parents of a 21-year-old student ask you to contact the institution their daughter is studying in to obtain her results. You contact the institution and ask if you can have a copy of her academic results. The institution should:

Answer options:
Give the information to the parents as they have paid for the student to be in the program.
Only give the results to the parents through you after asking the student for permission to do this and obtaining this permission in writing as privacy laws require.
Not give the information to the parents as required by migration laws.
Not give the information to the parents unless they pay the institution a fee.
correct_answers: Only give the results to the parents through you after asking the student for permission to do this and obtaining this permission in writing as privacy laws require.
extracted_answers: Only give the results to the parents through you after asking the student for permission to do this and obtaining this permission in writing as privacy laws require.
question_results.full_response:
## Report on Disclosure of Student Academic Results to Parents in Australia

**Introduction**

This report addresses the scenario where parents of a 21-year-old student request access to their daughter's academic results from the educational institution she attends in Australia. The core issue revolves around the institution's legal and ethical obligations concerning student privacy and whether it can disclose this information to the parents without the student's consent. This report will analyze the relevant privacy laws, university policies, and general practices within the Australian higher education sector to determine the appropriate course of action for the institution.

**Analysis of the Scenario**

The scenario presents a common dilemma faced by universities and other educational institutions in Australia. While parents may have a vested interest in their adult child's academic progress, particularly if they are financially supporting their education, Australian privacy laws prioritize the student's right to control their personal information. The key legal frameworks governing this situation include the *Privacy Act 1988* (Cth) and, in some cases, state-based privacy legislation.

**Relevant Legislation and Principles**

1.  **Privacy Act 1988 (Cth):** This Act regulates the handling of personal information by Australian Government agencies and private sector organizations with an annual turnover of more than $3 million AUD. While most public universities are not directly governed by the *Privacy Act 1988* (Cth), except for private universities and the Australian National University ([MinterEllison](https://www.minterellison.com/articles/privacy-reforms-in-australias-higher-education-sector)), they often adhere to its principles or are subject to similar state or territory-based privacy laws ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/higher-education-publications/higher-education-administrative-information-providers-october-2021/40-privacy-requirements)). The Act includes the Australian Privacy Principles (APPs), which outline how personal information should be collected, used, disclosed, and stored ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/higher-education-publications/higher-education-administrative-information-providers-october-2021/40-privacy-requirements)).

2.  **State and Territory Privacy Laws:** Since many public universities are not directly covered by the *Privacy Act 1988* (Cth), they are subject to state and territory privacy laws. For example, in New South Wales, the *Privacy and Personal Information Protection Act 1998* (NSW) applies ([UNSW Current Students](https://www.student.unsw.edu.au/supporters)). In Victoria, the *Privacy and Data Protection Act 2014* (Vic) is relevant ([Federation University Australia](https://policy.federation.edu.au/corporate_governance/procedures/information_privacy/ch01.php)). These laws establish similar principles to the APPs, emphasizing the protection of personal information and individual rights.

3.  **Australian Privacy Principles (APPs):** These principles, found in Schedule 1 of the *Privacy Act 1988* (Cth), dictate how organizations must handle personal information. APP 6 specifically addresses the use and disclosure of personal information. It states that personal information should only be used or disclosed for the purpose for which it was collected (the "primary purpose"), unless an exception applies ([Department of Education, Australian Government](https://www.education.gov.au/higher-education-publications/higher-education-administrative-information-providers-october-2021/40-privacy-requirements)). Disclosure to parents without the student's consent would generally not fall under the primary purpose.

**University Policies and Practices**

Universities in Australia generally have strict policies regarding student privacy. These policies are designed to comply with relevant legislation and to protect the confidentiality of student information.

1.  **Student Privacy Policies:** Universities typically have comprehensive privacy policies that outline their obligations under privacy laws and how they handle student information ([Australian National University](https://www.anu.edu.au/students/contacts/consent-to-the-disclosure-of-personal-information-process)). These policies often state that the university will not disclose personal information, including academic results, to third parties without the student's consent ([UNSW Current Students](https://www.student.unsw.edu.au/supporters)).

2.  **Consent Requirements:** To disclose a student's academic results to their parents, the university generally requires the student's explicit consent. This consent is often obtained through a formal authorization process, such as a "Third Party Authorisation" form ([UNSW Current Students](https://www.student.unsw.edu.au/supporters)). This form allows the student to specify what information can be released and to whom.

3.  **Age of Majority:** In Australia, the age of majority is 18 years. Once a student reaches this age, they are generally considered to have the right to control their own personal information. Therefore, even if parents are financially supporting their child's education, the university is still obligated to respect the student's privacy rights.

4.  **Exceptions:** There are limited exceptions to the general rule of non-disclosure. For example, a university may be required to disclose information if compelled by law or a court order ([Federation University Australia](https://policy.federation.edu.au/corporate_governance/procedures/information_privacy/ch01.php)). However, these exceptions are narrowly defined and would not typically apply to a request from parents for their adult child's academic results.

**Analysis of Answer Options**

Based on the legal framework and university practices discussed above, let's analyze the provided answer options:

*   **Give the information to the parents as they have paid for the student to be in the program:** This option is incorrect. While the parents' financial contribution is a factor, it does not override the student's right to privacy. Universities are legally obligated to protect student information, regardless of who is paying for their education.

*   **Only give the results to the parents through you after asking the student for permission to do this and obtaining this permission in writing as privacy laws require:** This option is the most accurate. It aligns with the principles of the *Privacy Act 1988* (Cth) and state-based privacy laws, as well as the policies and practices of most Australian universities. Obtaining the student's written consent is crucial to ensure compliance with privacy obligations.

*   **Not give the information to the parents as required by migration laws:** This option is misleading. Migration laws are not the primary consideration in this scenario. While international students have specific obligations under migration laws ([Kangaroo Edu](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/migration-2025-effects-on-international-students-in-australia/)), these laws do not directly prevent the disclosure of academic results to parents with the student's consent.

*   **Not give the information to the parents unless they pay the institution a fee:** This option is incorrect. Universities do not typically charge a fee for releasing student information to authorized third parties. The primary concern is obtaining the student's consent, not financial compensation.

**Conclusion and Recommendation**

In conclusion, the institution should **only give the results to the parents through you after asking the student for permission to do this and obtaining this permission in writing as privacy laws require.** This approach respects the student's privacy rights, complies with relevant legislation, and aligns with the policies and practices of Australian universities.

**Recommendations:**

1.  **Contact the Student:** The institution should first contact the student and explain that their parents have requested access to their academic results.

2.  **Obtain Consent:** The institution should ask the student if they consent to the release of their academic results to their parents. This consent should be obtained in writing, using a formal authorization form if available.

3.  **Document the Process:** The institution should document all steps taken in the process, including the student's consent and any communication with the parents.

4.  **Provide Information (if authorized):** If the student provides consent, the institution can then release the academic results to the parents, ensuring that the information is provided securely and confidentially.

5.  **Refuse Disclosure (if no consent):** If the student does not provide consent, the institution must refuse to disclose the information to the parents, explaining that they are obligated to protect the student's privacy.

By following these recommendations, the institution can navigate this situation ethically and legally, upholding its obligations to protect student privacy while also addressing the parents' request for information.

**Additional Considerations**

*   **Cultural Sensitivity:** In some cultures, family relationships and expectations may place greater emphasis on parental involvement in their adult children's lives. However, Australian privacy laws do not make exceptions based on cultural norms. Universities should be sensitive to these cultural differences but must still adhere to legal requirements.

*   **Student Wellbeing:** If the student is reluctant to provide consent due to concerns about their parents' reaction, the university may offer support services or counseling to help the student manage the situation.

*   **Regular Policy Review:** Universities should regularly review their privacy policies and procedures to ensure they are up-to-date with changes in legislation and best practices. The *Privacy and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2024* (Cth) introduces reforms that the higher education sector needs to stay informed about to adapt to these reforms ([MinterEllison](https://www.minterellison.com/articles/privacy-reforms-in-australias-higher-education-sector)).

**References**

Department of Education, Australian Government. (2021, October). *Higher education administrative information providers - October 2021*. [https://www.education.gov.au/higher-education-publications/higher-education-administrative-information-providers-october-2021/40-privacy-requirements](https://www.education.gov.au/higher-education-publications/higher-education-administrative-information-providers-october-2021/40-privacy-requirements)

Federation University Australia. *Information Privacy Procedure*. [https://policy.federation.edu.au/corporate_governance/procedures/information_privacy/ch01.php](https://policy.federation.edu.au/corporate_governance/procedures/information_privacy/ch01.php)

Kangaroo Edu. (2024, October 30). *Migration 2025: Effects on International Students in Australia*. [https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/migration-2025-effects-on-international-students-in-australia/](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/migration-2025-effects-on-international-students-in-australia/)

MinterEllison. (2024, November 4). *Privacy reforms in Australia's higher education sector - Insight*. [https://www.minterellison.com/articles/privacy-reforms-in-australias-higher-education-sector](https://www.minterellison.com/articles/privacy-reforms-in-australias-higher-education-sector)

UNSW Current Students. *Information for Parents/Guardians on Student Privacy*. [https://www.student.unsw.edu.au/supporters](https://www.student.unsw.edu.au/supporters)

question_results.question:
When a student has been reported to DHA by the education provider, DHA will send a letter to the student asking them to explain their circumstances to DHA. How long does the student have to contact DHA and make an appointment?

Answer options:
20 days
5 days
35 days
28 days
correct_answers: 28 days
extracted_answers: 28 days
question_results.full_response:
## Report on Timeframe for Student Response to DHA Notification in Australia

The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) in Australia plays a crucial role in managing student visas and ensuring compliance with visa conditions. When an education provider reports a student to the DHA due to concerns such as unsatisfactory academic performance or attendance, the DHA typically sends a notification to the student, requesting an explanation of their circumstances. Determining the precise timeframe a student has to respond to this notification is critical for ensuring compliance and avoiding potential visa cancellation. Based on the provided information, this report aims to clarify the response timeframe, the processes involved, and related considerations for international students in Australia.

### Determining the Response Timeframe

The key timeframe for a student to contact the DHA and potentially make an appointment after receiving a notification of a potential visa breach is **28 days**. This conclusion is supported by several sources within the provided information:

*   **Charter Australia Policy:** The policy document from Charter Australia states that when notifying a student of a breach (e.g., unsatisfactory academic performance), the notice must state that the student is required to attend before an officer within 28 days to explain the breach ([Charter.edu.au](https://charter.edu.au/policies/notifying-det-and-dha-for-international-students)).
*   **Automatic Cancellation:** A [Mondaq.com](https://www.mondaq.com/australia/general-immigration/1302830/automatic-cancellation-of-student-visas) article discusses Section 137J of the Migration Act, noting that the DHA will automatically cancel a student visa if the holder does not contact the Department within 28 days of a Section 20 notice.
*   **VisaEnvoy:** [VisaEnvoy](https://visaenvoy.com/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation/) confirms that for certain questions in a Notice of Intention to Consider Cancellation, a student has 28 days from the date of the notice to respond.

Therefore, the most accurate answer, based on the provided documentation, is **28 days**.

### Contextualizing the 28-Day Timeframe

It is essential to understand the context surrounding this 28-day timeframe. The DHA's notification is typically a "Notice of Intention to Consider Cancellation" (NOICC). This notice is a formal communication informing the student that the DHA is considering cancelling their visa due to a potential breach of visa conditions. The notice outlines the reasons for the potential cancellation and invites the student to provide information and explanations as to why their visa should not be cancelled.

**Key Components of the NOICC and Response:**

1.  **Reasons for Concern:** The NOICC will detail the specific reasons why the DHA is considering cancelling the visa. These reasons often relate to:

    *   **Attendance:** Failing to meet the minimum attendance requirements as set by the education provider and the DHA ([Education.vic.gov.au](https://www2.education.vic.gov.au/pal/international-student-program/print-all)).
    *   **Academic Performance:** Unsatisfactory academic progress, as defined by the education provider ([Charter.edu.au](https://charter.edu.au/policies/notifying-det-and-dha-for-international-students)).
    *   **Breach of Other Visa Conditions:** Violating other conditions of the student visa, such as working more hours than permitted or engaging in activities that are not allowed under the visa ([Study International](https://studyinternational.com/news/australian-student-visa-delays-tips/)).
2.  **Student's Response:** The student has the opportunity to respond to the NOICC by providing information and evidence to address the DHA's concerns. This response may include:

    *   **Explanation of Circumstances:** A detailed explanation of the reasons for the alleged breach, such as illness, family issues, or other extenuating circumstances.
    *   **Supporting Documentation:** Evidence to support the student's explanation, such as medical certificates, letters from counselors, or other relevant documents.
    *   **Steps Taken to Rectify the Situation:** Information about the steps the student has taken or plans to take to address the issues, such as enrolling in additional classes, seeking academic support, or improving attendance.
3.  **DHA's Consideration:** After receiving the student's response, the DHA will consider the information provided and make a decision on whether to cancel the visa. The DHA may also request additional information or clarification from the student.

### Calculating the Time Limit

[VisaEnvoy](https://visaenvoy.com/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation/) provides detailed instructions on how to calculate the time limit to respond to a Notice of Intention to Consider Cancellation. The calculation depends on how the notice was delivered:

*   **Posted:** Add 7 working days to the date on the last page of the notice, then add 28 days (including weekends).
*   **Faxed or Emailed:** Add 28 days (including weekends) from the date on the letter (not the date received, unless it was the same day).

### Importance of Responding Promptly

It is crucial for students to respond to the NOICC within the specified timeframe. Failure to do so can result in automatic visa cancellation ([Mondaq.com](https://www.mondaq.com/australia/general-immigration/1302830/automatic-cancellation-of-student-visas)). Even if the student submits information after the deadline, the DHA is still obligated to consider it if a decision has not yet been made ([VisaEnvoy](https://visaenvoy.com/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation/)). However, it is always best to adhere to the given timeframe.

### Factors Influencing Visa Cancellation Decisions

Several factors can influence the DHA's decision on whether to cancel a student visa:

*   **Seriousness of the Breach:** The more serious the breach of visa conditions, the more likely the DHA is to cancel the visa.
*   **Student's Explanation:** A clear and compelling explanation of the circumstances surrounding the breach can increase the chances of the DHA deciding not to cancel the visa.
*   **Evidence Provided:** Providing strong evidence to support the student's explanation can significantly strengthen their case.
*   **Student's Compliance History:** A history of compliance with visa conditions can be a positive factor in the DHA's decision-making process.
*   **University Support:** Support from the student's university, such as a letter of support or evidence of academic assistance, can also be helpful.

### Recent Trends and Challenges in Student Visas

Recent years have seen increased scrutiny of student visa applications and processing, influenced by factors such as:

*   **Increased Application Volumes:** The DHA has been grappling with a large volume of student visa applications, particularly after the reopening of Australian borders following COVID-19 ([Study International](https://studyinternational.com/news/australian-student-visa-delays-tips/)).
*   **Concerns About Non-Genuine Applicants:** The DHA has expressed concerns about student visas being issued to non-genuine applicants, leading to increased scrutiny and stricter enforcement of visa conditions ([Study International](https://studyinternational.com/news/australian-student-visa-delays-tips/)).
*   **Visa Processing Delays:** Delays in visa processing have been a significant issue, causing frustration and anxiety for international students ([Study International](https://studyinternational.com/news/australian-student-visa-delay/)).
*   **Government Policy Changes:** Recent policy changes, such as capping international student numbers and repealing Ministerial Direction 107, have added complexity to the student visa landscape ([SBS News](https://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/the-government-has-revealed-international-student-caps-from-2025-whats-been-announced/lu4rn9059)).

### Recommendations for International Students

To avoid potential visa issues and ensure compliance with visa conditions, international students in Australia should:*   **Understand Visa Conditions:** Thoroughly understand the conditions of their student visa and ensure they comply with all requirements.
*   **Maintain Satisfactory Attendance and Academic Performance:** Attend classes regularly and maintain satisfactory academic progress.
*   **Seek Support When Needed:** Seek assistance from their university or other support services if they are struggling with their studies or facing personal challenges.
*   **Respond Promptly to DHA Communications:** Respond promptly and thoroughly to any communications from the DHA, including NOICCs.
*   **Seek Legal Advice:** If they receive a NOICC, consider seeking legal advice from an experienced immigration lawyer.*   **Keep Updated:** Stay informed about any changes to visa regulations or policies.

### Conclusion

In summary, when a student has been reported to the DHA by their education provider and receives a "Notice of Intention to Consider Cancellation," they generally have **28 days** to contact the DHA and provide an explanation of their circumstances. This timeframe is critical, and students should prioritize responding within this period to avoid potential visa cancellation. Understanding the context of the NOICC, the factors influencing DHA decisions, and recent trends in student visas is essential for international students to navigate the Australian visa system successfully. By adhering to visa conditions, seeking support when needed, and responding promptly to DHA communications, students can minimize the risk of visa cancellation and ensure a positive study experience in Australia.

### References

*   Charter Australia. (n.d.). *Policy - Notifying DET and DHA for International Students*. [https://charter.edu.au/policies/notifying-det-and-dha-for-international-students](https://charter.edu.au/policies/notifying-det-and-dha-for-international-students)
*   Mondaq. (2023, May 10). *Automatic cancellation of student visas - General Immigration - Australia*. [https://www.mondaq.com/australia/general-immigration/1302830/automatic-cancellation-of-student-visas](https://www.mondaq.com/australia/general-immigration/1302830/automatic-cancellation-of-student-visas)
*   SBS News. (2024, December 19). *The government has revealed international student caps from 2025. What's been announced?*. [https://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/the-government-has-revealed-international-student-caps-from-2025-whats-been-announced/lu4rn9059](https://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/the-government-has-revealed-international-student-caps-from-2025-whats-been-announced/lu4rn9059)
*   Study International Staff. (2022, April 28). *Australian student visa delays sparks frustration*. Study International. [https://studyinternational.com/news/australian-student-visa-delay/](https://studyinternational.com/news/australian-student-visa-delay/)
*   Study International Staff. (n.d.). *Australian student visa: 4 tips to avoid processing delays*. Study International. [https://studyinternational.com/news/australian-student-visa-delays-tips/](https://studyinternational.com/news/australian-student-visa-delays-tips/)
*   Victorian Department of Education and Training. (n.d.). *International Student Program (ISP)*. [https://www2.education.vic.gov.au/pal/international-student-program/print-all](https://www2.education.vic.gov.au/pal/international-student-program/print-all)
*   VisaEnvoy. (n.d.). *Notice of Intention to Consider Cancellation*. [https://visaenvoy.com/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation/](https://visaenvoy.com/notice-of-intention-to-consider-cancellation/)

question_results.question:
A student visa in Australia:

Answer options:
Is only necessary for students wanting to study at university.
Is issued by DET under the Australia Act 1986.
Is issued by DHA under the Migration Act 1958.
Requires all students to study in Australia for a minimum of three years.
correct_answers: Is issued by DHA under the Migration Act 1958.
extracted_answers: Is issued by DHA under the Migration Act 1958.
question_results.full_response:
## Australian Student Visa: An In-Depth Analysis of Requirements and Issuance

The pursuit of higher education in Australia attracts thousands of international students annually, drawn by the country's prestigious educational institutions and diverse study options ([Studies Overseas, 2024](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/student-visa-australia)). Navigating the Australian student visa system is a crucial step for prospective students. This report aims to provide a comprehensive analysis of the Australian student visa, specifically addressing the query: "A student visa in Australia: Is only necessary for students wanting to study at university; Is issued by DET under the Australia Act 1986; Is issued by DHA under the Migration Act 1958; Requires all students to study in Australia for a minimum of three years."

Based on the available information, the most accurate answer is: **Is issued by DHA under the Migration Act 1958.** This report will delve into the intricacies of the Australian student visa system, providing context and evidence to support this conclusion.

### The Australian Student Visa (Subclass 500)

The primary visa for international students seeking to undertake full-time education in Australia is the Student Visa (Subclass 500) ([Studies Overseas, 2024](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/student-visa-australia); [VEM Visa, n.d.](https://vemvisa.com/en/australian-visas/australian-student-visa/)). This visa allows eligible students to live and study in Australia for the duration of their course, up to a maximum of five years ([Study Australia, n.d.](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/student-visa-subclass-500); [VEM Visa, n.d.](https://vemvisa.com/en/australian-visas/australian-student-visa/)).

#### Issuance by the Department of Home Affairs (DHA)

The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) is the Australian government agency responsible for immigration and border control. It is the DHA that manages and issues student visas under the framework of the Migration Act 1958 ([Legislation, 2024](https://www.legislation.gov.au/C1958A00062/2024-07-01/2024-07-01/text/original/epub/OEBPS/document_2/document_2.html)). The Australia Act 1986, on the other hand, deals with the termination of the remaining legislative links between Australia and the United Kingdom and has no bearing on visa issuance ([Legislation, n.d.](No Legislation URL available)).

#### Scope Beyond University Studies

The assertion that a student visa is only necessary for university studies is incorrect. The Student Visa (Subclass 500) caters to a wide range of study types, including:

*   Higher education ([Study Australia, n.d.](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/student-visa-subclass-500))
*   Vocational Education and Training (VET) ([Study Australia, n.d.](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/student-visa-subclass-500))
*   Pathway courses ([Study Australia, n.d.](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/student-visa-subclass-500))
*   English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students (ELICOS) ([Study Australia, n.d.](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/student-visa-subclass-500))
*   Primary and secondary school ([Study Australia, n.d.](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/student-visa-subclass-500))
*   Non-award courses (such as Study Abroad and Exchange semesters) ([Study Australia, n.d.](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/student-visa-subclass-500))

Therefore, students pursuing various educational pathways, not just university degrees, require a student visa.

#### No Minimum Study Duration of Three Years

The claim that all students must study in Australia for a minimum of three years is also inaccurate. The duration of the Student Visa (Subclass 500) is directly linked to the length of the enrolled course ([Study Australia, n.d.](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/student-visa-subclass-500); [VEM Visa, n.d.](https://vemvisa.com/en/australian-visas/australian-student-visa/)). While the maximum stay is generally five years, students undertaking shorter courses will receive visas valid for the course duration plus a specified additional period ([Study Australia, n.d.](https://www.studyaustralia.gov.au/en/plan-your-move/your-guide-to-visas/student-visa-subclass-500); [Immigration, n.d.](https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/student-500/length-of-stay)).

### Key Requirements for the Student Visa (Subclass 500) in 2025

Several key requirements must be met to obtain a Student Visa (Subclass 500). These include:

*   **Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE):** As of January 1, 2025, a CoE is mandatory for all student visa applications, confirming acceptance into a registered course at an Australian educational institution ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025); [Visa and Immigrations, 2025](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/); [Get GIS, 2024](https://getgis.org/news/new-requirements-for-australia-student-visa-from-january-2025); [LinkedIn, n.d.](https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/student-visa-australia-major-updates-you-need-know-2025-banerjee-ldqpf)). Letters of Offer are no longer accepted for onshore applications ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025); [Visa and Immigrations, 2025](https://visaandimmigrations.com/australias-new-student-visa-rules-for-2025-key-changes-and-what-you-need-to-know/)).
*   **Genuine Student (GS) Requirement:** Replacing the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement, the GS assesses the applicant's intention to genuinely study in Australia ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)). This involves answering targeted questions about study plans, circumstances, and reasons for choosing Australia ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)).
*   **English Language Proficiency:** Applicants must demonstrate sufficient English language skills through recognized tests like IELTS, TOEFL iBT, PTE Academic, or Cambridge English: Advanced ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025); [VEM Visa, n.d.](https://vemvisa.com/en/australian-visas/australian-student-visa/)). The minimum IELTS score has increased to 6.0 for student visas ([VEM Visa, n.d.](https://vemvisa.com/en/australian-visas/australian-student-visa/)).
*   **Financial Capacity:** Applicants must provide evidence of sufficient funds to cover living expenses, tuition fees, and travel costs ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)). As of May 10, 2024, the required amount for living costs is A$29,710 per year ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)).
*   **Overseas Student Health Cover (OSHC):** All international students are required to have OSHC valid for the entire duration of their stay in Australia ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025); [Immigration, n.d.](https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/student-500/length-of-stay)).
*   **Health and Character Checks:** Applicants must meet health and character requirements, which may involve medical examinations and police certificates from countries where they have resided for 12 months or more in the past 10 years ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)).

### Application Process

The application process for the Student Visa (Subclass 500) involves several steps:

1.  **Course and Institution Selection:** Choose a study program and educational institution registered on CRICOS (Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students) ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025); [Studies Overseas, 2024](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/student-visa-australia)).
2.  **Acceptance and CoE:** Apply and get accepted into the course to receive a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025); [Studies Overseas, 2024](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/student-visa-australia)).
3.  **ImmiAccount Creation:** Create an account on the Department of Home Affairs website ([Studies Overseas, 2024](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/student-visa-australia)).
4.  **Visa Application Submission:** Complete the online visa application form and upload all required documents ([Studies Overseas, 2024](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/student-visa-australia); [Visa Verge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/australiaimmigration/australian-student-visa-subclass-500-requirements-application/)).
5.  **Visa Fee Payment:** Pay the application fee online ([Studies Overseas, 2024](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/student-visa-australia)). As of July 1, 2024, the fee is AUD 1,600 ([Insider Guides, 2025](https://insiderguides.com.au/australias-2025-visa-changes-what-international-students-need-to-know/)).
6.  **Biometric Data Submission:** Provide biometric data if requested ([Studies Overseas, 2024](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/student-visa-australia)).
7.  **Visa Decision:** Receive a notification of the visa decision ([Studies Overseas, 2024](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/student-visa-australia); [Visa Verge, 2025](https://www.visaverge.com/australiaimmigration/australian-student-visa-subclass-500-requirements-application/)).

### Visa Conditions and Rights

The Student Visa (Subclass 500) comes with specific conditions and rights:

*   **Study Condition:** Students must maintain enrolment in a registered course and maintain satisfactory course progress and attendance ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)).
*   **Work Rights:** Students can work up to 48 hours per fortnight during term time and unlimited hours during scheduled course breaks ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025); [Studies Overseas, 2024](https://www.studies-overseas.com/blogs/student-visa-australia)). Master by research or Doctoral students have no work hour limit ([Kangaroo Edu, 2025](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)).

### Conclusion

In conclusion, the statement that "A student visa in Australia is issued by DHA under the Migration Act 1958" is the most accurate among the given options. The Department of Home Affairs is the responsible authority for issuing student visas under the legal framework of the Migration Act 1958. The Student Visa (Subclass 500) caters to a diverse range of study types beyond university degrees, and the visa duration is directly tied to the length of the enrolled course, dispelling the notion of a mandatory three-year study period. Prospective students must carefully navigate the requirements and application process to successfully obtain their visa and embark on their educational journey in Australia.

### References

Bircan Migration. (2024, November 11). Who Can Sponsor Your Australian Student Visa?. [https://bircanmigration.com.au/who-can-sponsor-your-australian-student-visa/](https://bircanmigration.com.au/who-can-sponsor-your-australian-student-visa/)

CollegeDunia. (n.d.). Student Visa Australia (Subclass 500): Requirements, Fees & Processing Time. [https://collegedunia.com/australia/article/australian-student-visa-requirements-cost-processing-time-rejection-reasons](https://collegedunia.com/australia/article/australian-student-visa-requirements-cost-processing-time-rejection-reasons)

Get GIS. (2024, December 30). New Requirements for Australia Student Visa From January 2025. [https://getgis.org/news/new-requirements-for-australia-student-visa-from-january-2025](https://getgis.org/news/new-requirements-for-australia-student-visa-from-january-2025)

Immigration. (n.d.). Length of stay for Student visas. [https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/student-500/length-of-stay](https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-listing/student-500/length-of-stay)

Insider Guides. (2025). Australia’s 2025 Visa Changes: What International Students Need to Know - Insider Guides. [https://insiderguides.com.au/australias-2025-visa-changes-what-international-students-need-to-know/](https://insiderguides.com.au/australias-2025-visa-changes-what-international-students-need-to-know/)

Kangaroo Edu. (2025, January 10). Navigating Australian Student Visa Requirements in 2025: A Beginner’s Guide. [https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025/](https://kangarooedu.au/blogs/navigating-australian-student-visa-requirements-in-2025)
