question_results.question:
One of the counsellors in your office is undertaking training about the Australian education system. They are unsure about some of the information they have read. Which of the following would you advise them is True?

Answer options:
International students in Australian universities attend separate classes to local students.
A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.
International students receive better treatment than domestic students.
A student studying in an undergraduate program is more likely to enter into a Certificate IV than a Graduate diploma program upon completion of the undergraduate program.
correct_answers: A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.
extracted_answers: A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.
question_results.full_response:
# Report on the Australian Education System for Counselor Training

**Introduction**

This report addresses a counselor's query regarding the Australian education system, specifically focusing on key aspects relevant to international and domestic students. The aim is to clarify common misconceptions and provide accurate information to support effective counseling of prospective students. Based on the provided sources, the report will evaluate the truthfulness of the following statements:

1.  International students in Australian universities attend separate classes to local students.
2.  A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.
3.  International students receive better treatment than domestic students.
4.  A student studying in an undergraduate program is more likely to enter into a Certificate IV than a Graduate diploma program upon completion of the undergraduate program.

**Analysis of Statements**

**1. International students in Australian universities attend separate classes to local students.**

*   **Evaluation:** This statement is generally **false**.

*   **Explanation:** The provided sources do not indicate that international students are segregated into separate classes. Instead, the emphasis is on integrating international students into the broader university community. While entry requirements and fees may differ ([Cullen, 2024](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-01-15/university-offers-entry-scores-international-students-uni-fees/103314112)), the learning environment is typically co-educational, fostering interaction and collaboration between domestic and international students. The benefits of this integration include cross-cultural understanding, diverse perspectives in academic discussions, and enhanced global awareness for all students.

**2. A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College.**

*   **Evaluation:** This statement is **true**.

*   **Explanation:** The English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students (ELICOS) Attendance Policy at SCU College explicitly states that international students must maintain a minimum attendance rate of at least 80% for each study period ([SCU, n.d.](https://policies.scu.edu.au/document/view-current.php?id=203&version=3)). This requirement is in place to ensure that students are actively engaged in their language studies and are making satisfactory progress. Failure to meet this attendance requirement can lead to warnings, potential reporting to the relevant Commonwealth Department via PRISMS, and even exclusion from the course. In certain compassionate or compelling circumstances, the minimum attendance may be calculated to 70% of scheduled class hours, provided that documentary evidence is presented and the Director, ELP approves ([SCU, n.d.](https://policies.scu.edu.au/document/view-current.php?id=203&version=3)).

**3. International students receive better treatment than domestic students.**

*   **Evaluation:** This statement is **false**.

*   **Explanation:** The sources suggest that while international students are a valued part of the Australian higher education system, they do not receive preferential treatment over domestic students. In fact, in some instances, domestic students may have an advantage. For example, domestic students are eligible for Commonwealth Supported Places (CSPs), where the Australian government subsidizes a portion of their tuition fees ([OAU, n.d.](https://www.open.edu.au/advice/insights/tertiary-education-fees-in-australia)). International students, on the other hand, are required to pay full tuition fees ([UTAS, n.d.](https://askus.utas.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/1286/~/what-is-the-difference-between-domestic-and-international-fees?)). Additionally, entry requirements for some courses may be higher for domestic students than for international students ([Cullen, 2024](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-01-15/university-offers-entry-scores-international-students-uni-fees/103314112)). Universities strive to provide a positive experience for all students, as indicated by satisfaction surveys ([Australian Government, 2023](https://www.education.gov.au/newsroom/articles/domestic-and-international-students-happy-australian-higher-education-institutions)), but this does not equate to preferential treatment for international students.

**4. A student studying in an undergraduate program is more likely to enter into a Certificate IV than a Graduate diploma program upon completion of the undergraduate program.**

*   **Evaluation:** This statement is **false**.

*   **Explanation:** Upon completion of an undergraduate program (Bachelor's degree), a student is significantly more likely to pursue a Graduate Diploma or a Master's degree than a Certificate IV. An undergraduate degree is a higher qualification than a Certificate IV, and students typically aim to further their education at a postgraduate level to enhance their career prospects and knowledge base. Graduate Diplomas and Master's degrees build upon the knowledge gained during undergraduate studies, providing specialized skills and advanced understanding in a specific field. While some students may opt for vocational training (such as a Certificate IV) for specific career goals, it is not the typical pathway for undergraduate degree holders.

**Additional Considerations**

*   **Defining Domestic and International Students:** It is crucial to understand the definitions of domestic and international students. Domestic students are Australian or New Zealand citizens, or permanent Australian visa holders ([UWA, n.d.](https://www.ask.uwa.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/1001/~/domestic-and-international-student-definitions)). International students are citizens of any other country temporarily living in Australia for the purpose of study ([UWA, n.d.](https://www.ask.uwa.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/1001/~/domestic-and-international-student-definitions)).

*   **University Funding:** The Australian government provides funding for university places for domestic students. The number of university places available to Australian students is largely determined by the level of Commonwealth funding provided ([Cullen, 2024](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-01-15/university-offers-entry-scores-international-students-uni-fees/103314112)). Universities also generate revenue from international student fees, which contributes to the overall financial sustainability of the institutions.

*   **Entry Requirements:** Entry requirements for international students may differ from those for domestic students ([Cullen, 2024](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-01-15/university-offers-entry-scores-international-students-uni-fees/103314112)). Universities consider various factors, including academic qualifications from overseas education systems, English language proficiency, and the demand for specific courses.

*   **Student Satisfaction:** Surveys indicate that both domestic and international students are generally satisfied with their experiences studying in Australia ([Australian Government, 2023](https://www.education.gov.au/newsroom/articles/domestic-and-international-students-happy-australian-higher-education-institutions)). International students often cite personal safety and security as a key reason for choosing Australia as their study destination ([Australian Government, 2023](https://www.education.gov.au/newsroom/articles/domestic-and-international-students-happy-australian-higher-education-institutions)).

*   **Trends in International Education:** As of 2025, there is a rising demand for Australian education, driven by globally recognized qualifications and career outcomes ([Darlo, 2025](https://darlohighereducation.com/international-student-trends-in-australia-2024/)). While China and India remain key source countries, diversification is increasing with emerging markets like Vietnam, Nepal, and Indonesia ([Darlo, 2025](https://darlohighereducation.com/international-student-trends-in-australia-2024/)). There is also a shift in preferred fields of study, with increasing interest in STEM and health sciences ([Darlo, 2025](https://darlohighereducation.com/international-student-trends-in-australia-2024/)).

*   **ELICOS Attendance Policy Details:** SCU College informs students of the importance of meeting the minimum attendance requirements at orientation meetings for new students ([SCU, n.d.](https://policies.scu.edu.au/document/view-current.php?id=203&version=3)). Teachers monitor attendance and inform students of their attendance percentage weekly. International Student Support issues warning letters if attendance falls below 90%, 85%, and 80% ([SCU, n.d.](https://policies.scu.edu.au/document/view-current.php?id=203&version=3)).

**Conclusion**

In conclusion, based on the available information, the counselor should be advised that the statement "A student should attend at least 80% of all scheduled lessons in an ELICOS College" is true. The other statements are false, as international students typically attend the same classes as local students, do not receive better treatment, and are more likely to pursue postgraduate studies than vocational training after completing their undergraduate program. Understanding these nuances is essential for providing accurate and effective guidance to prospective students interested in the Australian education system.

**References**

Australian Government, Department of Education. (2023, June 27). *Domestic and international students happy at Australian higher education institutions*. [https://www.education.gov.au/newsroom/articles/domestic-and-international-students-happy-australian-higher-education-institutions](https://www.education.gov.au/newsroom/articles/domestic-and-international-students-happy-australian-higher-education-institutions)

Cullen, S. (2024, January 15). *Why are tertiary entry requirements different for international and domestic students?* ABC News. [https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-01-15/university-offers-entry-scores-international-students-uni-fees/103314112](https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-01-15/university-offers-entry-scores-international-students-uni-fees/103314112)

Darlo Higher Education. (2025, February 3). *International student trends in Australia 2025: An overview*. [https://darlohighereducation.com/international-student-trends-in-australia-2024/](https://darlohighereducation.com/international-student-trends-in-australia-2024/)

Open Universities Australia (OAU). (n.d.). *How do tertiary education fees work in Australia?* [https://www.open.edu.au/advice/insights/tertiary-education-fees-in-australia](https://www.open.edu.au/advice/insights/tertiary-education-fees-in-australia)

Southern Cross University (SCU). (n.d.). *English Language Intensive Courses for Overseas Students (ELICOS) Attendance Policy*. [https://policies.scu.edu.au/document/view-current.php?id=203&version=3](https://policies.scu.edu.au/document/view-current.php?id=203&version=3)University of Tasmania (UTAS). (n.d.). *What is the difference between domestic and international fees?* Ask Us. [https://askus.utas.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/1286/~/what-is-the-difference-between-domestic-and-international-fees?](https://askus.utas.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/1286/~/what-is-the-difference-between-domestic-and-international-fees?)

University of Western Australia (UWA). (n.d.). *Domestic and international student definitions*. askUWA. [https://www.ask.uwa.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/1001/~/domestic-and-international-student-definitions](https://www.ask.uwa.edu.au/app/answers/detail/a_id/1001/~/domestic-and-international-student-definitions)

question_results.question:
Unsatisfactory academic performance means:

Answer options:
That a student has not attended class to the 80% required.
That a student has not achieved the required English levels necessary to enter an undergraduate program.
That a student has failed the majority of their subjects and would be unable to continue studying in their current course.
correct_answers: That a student has failed the majority of their subjects and would be unable to continue studying in their current course.
extracted_answers: That a student has failed the majority of their subjects and would be unable to continue studying in their current course.
question_results.full_response:
## Understanding Unsatisfactory Academic Performance in Australian Higher Education

The concept of "unsatisfactory academic performance" in Australian higher education is multifaceted and context-dependent. It is not simply a matter of failing a few subjects, nor is it solely tied to attendance or English language proficiency. Instead, it represents a failure to meet the academic standards and progression requirements set by a specific university for a particular course of study. Based on the provided information, the most accurate interpretation of unsatisfactory academic performance is that **a student has failed the majority of their subjects and would be unable to continue studying in their current course.** This report will delve into the nuances of this definition, exploring the criteria used to assess academic performance, the consequences of failing to meet these standards, and the broader context of academic performance trends in Australia.

### Defining Unsatisfactory Academic Performance

Several universities have specific procedures for managing students who fail to achieve satisfactory academic performance. James Cook University (JCU), for example, defines "Satisfactory Academic Performance" as a student who must: pass all core subjects; maintain a course Grade Point Average (GPA) of 4.00 or above; and pass more than 50% of completed credit points ([JCU](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)). This definition highlights the key components of academic performance assessment:

*   **Subject Grades:** Passing core subjects is a fundamental requirement. Failure in core subjects often triggers an "Academic Caution" or "Conditional" status, depending on the specific subject and the number of attempts ([JCU](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)).
*   **Grade Point Average (GPA):** Maintaining a minimum GPA is crucial. A GPA below a certain threshold (e.g., 4.00 at JCU) indicates an overall lack of academic achievement, even if all subjects are passed ([JCU](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)).*   **Credit Point Completion:** Passing more than 50% of completed credit points is essential for demonstrating satisfactory progress. Failing a significant portion of enrolled subjects, even if the GPA is above the minimum, can lead to academic probation or exclusion ([JCU](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)).

The University of Melbourne also has an "Academic Progress Review Policy (Coursework)" which states that a student’s progress is unsatisfactory if the student reaches the maximum time to complete a course without completing the requirements of that course; fails to meet a condition which has been imposed as part of an earlier academic progress review process; withdraws after the census date or after the last date to withdraw without incurring a fail grade from all enrolled subjects in the progress review period for the second time; or, is enrolled in an undergraduate course or graduate ([Melbourne Uni](https://policy.unimelb.edu.au/MPF1291/)).

The University of Sydney identifies students "at risk" if they have only successfully completed 50 percent or less of the credit points attempted or fail a barrier unit of study, compulsory unit, field work, clinical work, practicum or other professional experience for the first time ([Sydney Uni](https://www.sydney.edu.au/students/academic-progression.html)).

The University of Southern Queensland (USQ) has three stages of academic progress: Priority Student, Assisted Student, and At risk of Exclusion ([USQ](https://policy.unisq.edu.au/documents/13566PL)). A student who has been an Assisted Student for at least one Study Period and Failed 50% or more of the Courses attempted in their most recent Study Period as a stage 2 student; Failed the same Course, or its equivalent, a third time; or Failed a compulsory WIL, practicum, placement or project Course for a second time will be placed at risk of exclusion ([USQ](https://policy.unisq.edu.au/documents/13566PL)).

### Consequences of Unsatisfactory Academic Performance

Failing to meet the required academic standards can have serious consequences for students, including:

*   **Academic Probation/Caution:** This is an initial warning that performance is below the required level. Students may be required to develop an intervention plan or meet with an academic advisor ([JCU](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)).
*   **Conditional Enrolment:** Students may be allowed to continue their studies but with specific conditions, such as limiting the number of subjects they can enroll in or requiring them to seek additional academic support ([JCU](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)).
*   **Exclusion:** This is the most severe consequence, where a student is not permitted to continue in their current course. In some cases, they may also be barred from transferring to a similar course ([JCU](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)). At JCU, a student wishing to continue a course from which they have previously been given academic exclusion may apply to return to study in accordance with the Coursework Enrolment Procedure if a period of two (2) years has elapsed from the date of the academic exclusion, and the course is not listed in List 4 ([JCU](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)).
*   **Impact on International Student Visas:** For international students, failing to maintain satisfactory academic progress can lead to visa cancellation, as it violates the conditions of their student visa ([JCU](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)).

### Addressing Unsatisfactory Academic Performance

Universities typically have processes in place to support students who are struggling academically. These may include:

*   **Early Intervention Programs:** Identifying students at risk early on and providing them with targeted support and advice ([Melbourne Uni](https://policy.unimelb.edu.au/MPF1291/)).
*   **Academic Advising:** Offering guidance on study skills, time management, and course selection ([Sydney Uni](https://www.sydney.edu.au/students/academic-progression.html)).
*   **Support Services:** Providing access to counseling, disability services, and other resources to address factors that may be affecting academic performance ([Melbourne Uni](https://policy.unimelb.edu.au/MPF1291/)).
*   **Appeals Processes:** Allowing students to appeal decisions related to their academic status if they believe there were extenuating circumstances ([JCU](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)).

### Broader Context: Academic Performance Trends in Australia

While individual student performance is crucial, it is also important to consider the broader trends in academic achievement in Australia. There is some debate about whether Australian students are experiencing a decline in academic performance. Some sources suggest that Australian schoolchildren are sliding down international tests that measure their academic performance and are static, at best, on national tests on literacy and numeracy ([Hare](https://www.afr.com/work-and-careers/education/why-australia-s-students-keep-falling-behind-20220928-p5blna)). The OECD's 2022 Programme for International Student Assessment (PISA) scores show declines in mathematics, reading, and science scores for Australian students compared to previous years ([Harkin](https://ipa.org.au/publications-ipa/media-releases/latest-pisa-rankings-confirm-long-term-decline-in-australian-student-achievement)).

However, other research suggests that this narrative is not entirely accurate. A study by Dr. Sally Larsen at the University of New England argues that student achievement is only declining in the PISA assessments and that largescale assessment data does not support a prevailing narrative that Australian school students are declining in their ability to attain critical academic skills ([UNE](https://www.une.edu.au/connect/news/2024/05/data-defies-picture-of-academic-decline-in-australian-schools)).

These conflicting perspectives highlight the complexity of assessing academic performance trends and the need to consider multiple data sources and assessment methods.

### Factors Contributing to Academic Performance

Several factors can influence a student's academic performance, including:

*   **Individual Learning Styles and Abilities:** Students have different strengths and weaknesses, and some may require more support to succeed academically.
*   **Socioeconomic Background:** Students from disadvantaged backgrounds may face barriers to education, such as lack of access to resources or support.
*   **Mental Health and Wellbeing:** Stress, anxiety, and other mental health issues can significantly impact academic performance.
*   **Teaching Quality and Curriculum:** The quality of teaching and the relevance of the curriculum can influence student engagement and learning outcomes.
*   **University Support Services:** The availability and accessibility of academic support services can help students overcome academic challenges.

### Conclusion

In conclusion, unsatisfactory academic performance in Australian higher education is a complex issue with significant consequences for students. While attendance and English language proficiency are important factors, the primary indicator of unsatisfactory performance is the failure to meet the academic standards set by the university, typically involving failing the majority of subjects required to progress in their current course. This is usually determined by a combination of factors, including subject grades, GPA, and credit point completion. Universities have a responsibility to provide support services and early intervention programs to help students succeed, but ultimately, it is the student's responsibility to engage with these resources and maintain satisfactory academic progress. The broader trends in academic performance in Australia are a subject of ongoing debate, but it is clear that a multifaceted approach is needed to address the challenges facing students and ensure that they have the opportunity to achieve their full academic potential.

### References

Hare, J. (2022, September 28). School performance: Why Australia is falling behind. *Australian Financial Review*. [https://www.afr.com/work-and-careers/education/why-australia-s-students-keep-falling-behind-20220928-p5blna](https://www.afr.com/work-and-careers/education/why-australia-s-students-keep-falling-behind-20220928-p5blna)

Harkin, C. (2023, December 6). Latest PISA Rankings Confirm Long-Term Decline In Australian Student Achievement. *Institute of Public Affairs*. [https://ipa.org.au/publications-ipa/media-releases/latest-pisa-rankings-confirm-long-term-decline-in-australian-student-achievement](https://ipa.org.au/publications-ipa/media-releases/latest-pisa-rankings-confirm-long-term-decline-in-australian-student-achievement)

James Cook University. (n.d.). Unsatisfactory Academic Performance Procedure - Policy - JCU Australia. [https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure](https://www.jcu.edu.au/policy/academic-governance/student-experience/unsatisfactory-academic-performance-procedure)

University of Melbourne. (2022, December 22). Academic Progress Review Policy (Coursework). [https://policy.unimelb.edu.au/MPF1291/](https://policy.unimelb.edu.au/MPF1291/)

University of New England. (2024, May 22). Data defies picture of academic decline in Australian schools. [https://www.une.edu.au/connect/news/2024/05/data-defies-picture-of-academic-decline-in-australian-schools](https://www.une.edu.au/connect/news/2024/05/data-defies-picture-of-academic-decline-in-australian-schools)

University of Southern Queensland. (n.d.). Student Academic Progress Procedure. [https://policy.unisq.edu.au/documents/13566PL](https://policy.unisq.edu.au/documents/13566PL)

University of Sydney. (n.d.). Academic progression. [https://www.sydney.edu.au/students/academic-progression.html](https://www.sydney.edu.au/students/academic-progression.html)

question_results.question:
Which of the following statements about student visas is True?

Answer options:
The process an individual goes through in order to obtain a student visa is the same for everyone regardless of nationality or institution they will study with.
Students under 18 enrolling in a High School program do not need a student visa as they are not considered adults.
When the visa application states that an individual must be of good character, this means that they must have no criminal record or poor previous visa compliance record.
There is no fee payable to apply for a student visa.
correct_answers: When the visa application states that an individual must be of good character, this means that they must have no criminal record or poor previous visa compliance record.
extracted_answers: When the visa application states that an individual must be of good character, this means that they must have no criminal record or poor previous visa compliance record.
question_results.full_response:
## Student Visa Requirements for Australia: A Comprehensive Analysis

The pursuit of international education in Australia necessitates a thorough understanding of the country's student visa regulations. Navigating these requirements is crucial for prospective students aiming to study in Australia. Based on the provided information, this report aims to dissect the accuracy of a given statement regarding Australian student visas.

**Query:**

Which of the following statements about student visas is True?

**Answer options:**

*   The process an individual goes through in order to obtain a student visa is the same for everyone regardless of nationality or institution they will study with.
*   Students under 18 enrolling in a High School program do not need a student visa as they are not considered adults.
*   When the visa application states that an individual must be of good character, this means that they must have no criminal record or poor previous visa compliance record.
*   There is no fee payable to apply for a student visa.

**Report:**

After a careful review of the provided materials, the true statement about student visas is:

*   When the visa application states that an individual must be of good character, this means that they must have no criminal record or poor previous visa compliance record.

This report will elaborate on why this statement is accurate and why the other options are not.

### Character Requirements for Australian Visas

The Australian Department of Home Affairs (DHA) mandates that all visa applicants meet specific character requirements to ensure they do not pose a risk to the Australian community ([VisaVerge, n.d.](https://www.visaverge.com/guides/australia-visa-character-requirements-guide/)). This assessment involves scrutinizing an applicant's criminal history, past conduct, and general behavior to determine whether they align with Australian values and legal standards ([TravelPander, n.d.](https://travelpander.com/can-i-visit-australia-with-a-criminal-record/)).

#### Key Aspects of Character Assessment

1.  **Criminal History:** A clean criminal record is a primary factor in meeting the character requirement ([Education ONE, n.d.](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)). The DHA considers the nature, frequency, and severity of any criminal offenses ([VisaVerge, n.d.](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/immigrating-to-australia-with-a-criminal-record-can-you-do-it/)). Serious crimes, such as those against children, drug trafficking, and violence, are major violations that can lead to visa refusal ([Education ONE, n.d.](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)).

2.  **Immigration History:** Past compliance with visa conditions is crucial. Overstaying a visa, working without authorization, or providing false information are significant concerns ([Education ONE, n.d.](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)). Breaching visa conditions or having a history of visa refusals or cancellations raises doubts about an applicant's commitment to adhering to Australian laws ([Education ONE, n.d.](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)).

3.  **Conduct and Associations:** Applicants must not engage in conduct that is harmful or disruptive to the Australian community. This includes avoiding associations with groups suspected of criminal activities ([VisaVerge, n.d.](https://www.visaverge.com/guides/australia-visa-character-requirements-guide/)). Involvement in activities such as people smuggling, human trafficking, or war crimes can result in visa denial ([Education ONE, n.d.](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)).

4.  **Honesty and Transparency:** Being honest and transparent throughout the visa application process is essential ([VisaVerge, n.d.](https://www.visaverge.com/guides/australia-visa-character-requirements-guide/)). Applicants must disclose any past criminal activity and provide all required information to the Immigration Office ([VisaVerge, n.d.](https://www.visaverge.com/guides/australia-visa-character-requirements-guide/)). Providing false or misleading information, whether intentional or unintentional, is a serious offense that can jeopardize the visa application ([Education ONE, n.d.](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)).

#### Factors Considered in Character Evaluation

When assessing an applicant's character, the DHA considers several factors, including:

*   The nature and seriousness of any offenses ([TravelPander, n.d.](https://travelpander.com/can-i-visit-australia-with-a-criminal-record/)).
*   The sentence received for any criminal convictions ([TravelPander, n.d.](https://travelpander.com/can-i-visit-australia-with-a-criminal-record/)).
*   Evidence of rehabilitation and efforts to reform ([Education ONE, n.d.](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)).
*   Compliance with Australian laws and visa conditions ([Education ONE, n.d.](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)).
*   The applicant's overall conduct and behavior ([VisaVerge, n.d.](https://www.visaverge.com/guides/australia-visa-character-requirements-guide/)).

#### Steps for Applicants with a Criminal Record

Applicants with a criminal record should take the following steps to improve their chances of obtaining a visa:

1.  **Determine Eligibility:** Assess eligibility based on the nature and severity of the criminal record ([TravelPander, n.d.](https://travelpander.com/can-i-visit-australia-with-a-criminal-record/)).

2.  **Gather Documentation:** Collect all necessary documents, including court records and rehabilitation proof ([TravelPander, n.d.](https://travelpander.com/can-i-visit-australia-with-a-criminal-record/)).

3.  **Disclose Criminal History:** Truthfully disclose the criminal record in the visa application ([TravelPander, n.d.](https://travelpander.com/can-i-visit-australia-with-a-criminal-record/)).

4.  **Provide Context:** Submit a statement that offers context around past convictions and outlines any rehabilitation or changes in life since the offense ([VisaVerge, n.d.](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/immigrating-to-australia-with-a-criminal-record-can-you-do-it/)).

5.  **Seek Legal Advice:** Consider seeking legal advice or representation from an immigration lawyer experienced in dealing with complex cases ([VisaVerge, n.d.](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/immigrating-to-australia-with-a-criminal-record-can-you-do-it/)).

### Debunking the Other Statements

1.  **"The process an individual goes through in order to obtain a student visa is the same for everyone regardless of nationality or institution they will study with."** This statement is false. The student visa process varies based on several factors, including the applicant's nationality, the education provider, and the level of study. For instance, the introduction of the Genuine Student (GS) requirement in March 2024 replaced the Genuine Temporary Entrant (GTE) requirement, indicating a shift in how applicants are assessed ([Kansaz, n.d.](https://www.kansaz.in/blog/australia-study-visa-requirements)). Additionally, specific exemptions and carryover rules apply to certain applicants, such as those sponsored by Foreign Affairs or Defence, and secondary exchange students, who may not require a Confirmation of Enrolment (CoE) ([VisaVerge, n.d.](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)).

2.  **"Students under 18 enrolling in a High School program do not need a student visa as they are not considered adults."** This statement is incorrect. All international students, regardless of age, must hold a valid student visa to study in Australia ([Kansaz, n.d.](https://www.kansaz.in/blog/australia-study-visa-requirements)). For applicants under 18, additional welfare and custody arrangements must be in place ([Leverage Edu, n.d.](https://leverageedu.com/learn/student-visa-australia-age-limit/)). The minimum age for school students to apply for a student visa is 6 years, and there are specific age limits for different levels of study ([Kansaz, n.d.](https://www.kansaz.in/blog/australia-study-visa-requirements); [Leverage Edu, n.d.](https://leverageedu.com/learn/student-visa-australia-age-limit/)).

3.  **"There is no fee payable to apply for a student visa."** This statement is false. Applying for an Australian student visa involves several fees, including the base visa fee, dependent charges, biometrics fee, and medical exam costs ([TerraTern, n.d.](https://terratern.com/blog/australia-study-visa-fees/)). As of July 2024, the base visa fee is AUD 1,600 ([TerraTern, n.d.](https://terratern.com/blog/australia-study-visa-fees/)). Visa fees are subject to change, and applicants should monitor official sources for the latest updates ([Immigration News Australia, n.d.](https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-visa-costs-and-what-to-expect-in-2025/)).

### Conclusion

In conclusion, the statement that accurately reflects the requirements for an Australian student visa is that applicants must demonstrate good character, which includes having no criminal record or a history of poor visa compliance. The other options presented are demonstrably false based on the regulations and guidelines set forth by the Australian Department of Home Affairs. Prospective students should prioritize honesty, transparency, and adherence to all visa conditions to ensure a successful application.

### References

Education ONE. (n.d.). *A Guide for S57 Character Requirement for Student Visa Australia*. [https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/](https://www.educationone.net.au/blog/s57-character-requirement-student-visa-australia/)

Immigration News Australia. (n.d.). *Australian Visa Costs And What to Expect in 2025*. [https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-visa-costs-and-what-to-expect-in-2025/](https://immigrationnewsaustralia.com/australian-visa-costs-and-what-to-expect-in-2025/)

Leverage Edu. (n.d.). *What is the Student Visa Australia Age Limit in 2025?*. [https://leverageedu.com/learn/student-visa-australia-age-limit/](https://leverageedu.com/learn/student-visa-australia-age-limit/)TerraTern. (n.d.). *Australia Study Visa Fees: Tips, Apply, Requirements in 2025*. [https://terratern.com/blog/australia-study-visa-fees/](https://terratern.com/blog/australia-study-visa-fees/)

TravelPander. (n.d.). *Can I Visit Australia With A Criminal Record? Visa Eligibility And Travel Tips [Updated On 2025]*. [https://travelpander.com/can-i-visit-australia-with-a-criminal-record/](https://travelpander.com/can-i-visit-australia-with-a-criminal-record/)

VisaVerge. (n.d.). *Australia Visa Character Requirements Guide*. [https://www.visaverge.com/guides/australia-visa-character-requirements-guide/](https://www.visaverge.com/guides/australia-visa-character-requirements-guide/)

VisaVerge. (n.d.). *Australia Updates Student Visa Rules for 2025 to Ensure Genuine Applicants*. [https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/](https://www.visaverge.com/news/australia-updates-student-visa-rules-for-2025-to-ensure-genuine-applicants/)

VisaVerge. (n.d.). *Immigrating to Australia with a Criminal Record: Can You Do It?*. [https://www.visaverge.com/questions/immigrating-to-australia-with-a-criminal-record-can-you-do-it/](https://www.visaverge.com/questions/immigrating-to-australia-with-a-criminal-record-can-you-do-it/)

question_results.question:
As an education agent you recruited a 17-year- old student to study in an English program. The parents of the student have asked you to provide them with the student’s results. You ask the English College to give you these results. They:

Answer options:
Cannot give you the student’s results unless the student gives permission.
Ask you to pay a service fee before giving you the results.
Give you the student’s results as the student is under 18 and this is allowed by law.
correct_answers: Give you the student’s results as the student is under 18 and this is allowed by law.
extracted_answers: Cannot give you the student’s results unless the student gives permission.
question_results.full_response:
## Report on the Disclosure of a 17-Year-Old Student's Results to an Education Agent in Australia

**Introduction**

This report addresses the scenario of an education agent requesting the results of a 17-year-old student from an English college in Australia, at the behest of the student's parents. It analyzes whether the college can legally provide these results without the student's explicit consent, considering relevant Australian privacy laws and educational policies. The report will provide a definitive answer based on the available information, focusing on the legal and ethical obligations of the English college.

**Analysis of the Scenario**

The core issue revolves around the privacy rights of a minor (under 18 years of age) in Australia and the extent to which their educational information can be shared with third parties, including parents and education agents. Several factors influence the outcome:

1.  **Age of Consent and Privacy Rights:** While the age of consent for sexual activity varies between 16 and 17 across different Australian states and territories ([Criminal Law Group](https://www.criminallawgroup.com.au/legal-age-of-sexual-dating-consent-australia/)), the general principle is that individuals under 18 are considered minors. However, this does not automatically grant parents unrestricted access to their children's personal information, especially as teenagers approach adulthood.
2.  **Privacy Act and Amendments:** Australia's privacy laws are primarily governed by the *Privacy Act 1988* (Cth). Recent amendments, such as those introduced by the *Privacy and Other Legislation Amendment Act 2024*, aim to strengthen privacy protections and increase penalties for breaches ([LegalVision](https://legalvision.com.au/upcoming-privacy-act-reforms/)). These reforms emphasize the importance of transparency and individual rights regarding personal information.
3.  **Definition of Personal Information:** The *Privacy Act* defines "personal information" broadly to include any information or opinion about an identified individual, or an individual who is reasonably identifiable ([OAIC](https://www.oaic.gov.au/privacy/your-privacy-rights/what-is-personal-information)). A student's academic results clearly fall under this definition.
4.  **Australian Privacy Principles (APPs):** The APPs outline how organizations must handle personal information. APP 5 requires organizations to notify individuals about how their personal information is collected, used, and disclosed ([OAIC](https://www.oaic.gov.au/privacy/australian-privacy-principles)). APP 6 restricts the use and disclosure of personal information to the primary purpose for which it was collected, unless an exception applies.
5.  **Educational Policies on Student Records:** Educational institutions in Australia have specific policies regarding access to student records. For instance, the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) Education Directorate has a policy that emphasizes safeguarding student records from unauthorized access and using and disclosing personal information only within the requirements of privacy legislation ([ACT Education Directorate](https://www.education.act.gov.au/publications_and_policies/corporate-policies/student-administration/student-records/access-student-records-policy/access-student-records-policy)). These policies generally allow parents access to their child's records, but this access may be limited as the child approaches 18, depending on the circumstances.
6.  **Consent Requirements:** Both privacy laws and educational policies often require consent to use or disclose personal information, especially health information, unless an exception applies ([Victorian Department of Education](https://www2.education.vic.gov.au/pal/privacy-information-sharing/guidance/consent)). Exceptions may include situations where disclosure is required by law or necessary to prevent a serious threat to an individual's safety.

**Legal and Ethical Considerations**

Given the above, the English college must carefully consider its legal and ethical obligations before releasing the 17-year-old student's results to the education agent.

*   **Privacy Legislation:** The *Privacy Act* and the APPs are paramount. Disclosing the student's results without their consent would likely constitute a breach of APP 6, unless a valid exception applies. The fact that the parents requested the information through an education agent does not automatically override the student's privacy rights.
*   **Student's Capacity to Consent:** At 17, the student is approaching adulthood and is generally considered capable of making their own decisions regarding their personal information. While parents may have a legitimate interest in their child's academic progress, the student has a right to privacy.
*   **Educational Policy:** The college's own policies on student records will likely reflect the principles of the *Privacy Act*. These policies will likely stipulate that student information can only be released to third parties with the student's consent, unless there is a legal obligation to do so.
*   **Best Interests of the Student:** The college should also consider the best interests of the student. Releasing the results without the student's knowledge or consent could potentially damage the student's relationship with their parents or compromise their autonomy.

**Determining a Concrete and Valid Opinion**

Based on the analysis of the relevant Australian privacy laws, educational policies, and ethical considerations, the English college **cannot** provide the 17-year-old student's results to the education agent without the student's explicit permission.

This opinion is based on the following concrete reasons:

1.  **Privacy Act Compliance:** The *Privacy Act 1988* (Cth) and the Australian Privacy Principles (APPs) mandate that personal information, including academic results, cannot be disclosed without the individual's consent, unless a specific legal exception applies. No such exception is apparent in this scenario.
2.  **Student's Right to Privacy:** At 17, the student has a reasonable expectation of privacy regarding their personal information. Overriding this expectation simply because the parents have requested the information would be a violation of the student's rights.
3.  **Lack of Legal Obligation:** The college has no legal obligation to provide the student's results to the education agent or the parents without the student's consent. The parents' request does not create such an obligation.
4.  **Potential for Harm:** Disclosing the information without the student's consent could potentially harm the student's relationship with their parents or undermine their autonomy.

**Recommendations for the English College**

To handle this situation appropriately, the English college should:

1.  **Contact the Student:** The college should contact the 17-year-old student and explain that their parents have requested their results through the education agent.
2.  **Seek the Student's Consent:** The college should ask the student whether they consent to the release of their results to the education agent. The student should be informed of their right to refuse consent.
3.  **Document the Decision:** The college should document the student's decision, whether they consent or refuse consent.
4.  **Communicate with the Education Agent:** If the student consents, the college can release the results to the education agent. If the student refuses consent, the college should inform the education agent that they cannot release the results due to privacy reasons.
5.  **Review Privacy Policy:** The college should review its privacy policy to ensure it clearly outlines the process for handling requests for student information and the importance of obtaining consent.
6.  **Train Staff:** The college should provide training to its staff on privacy laws and policies, emphasizing the importance of protecting student information.

**Conclusion**

In conclusion, the English college is legally and ethically obligated to protect the privacy of its students. Releasing the 17-year-old student's results to the education agent without the student's explicit consent would be a violation of Australian privacy laws and the student's right to privacy. The college must prioritize the student's rights and follow the recommended steps to ensure compliance and ethical conduct. The correct answer is: Cannot give you the student’s results unless the student gives permission.

**Reference List**

ACT Education Directorate. (2017, May). *Access Student Records Policy*. [https://www.education.act.gov.au/publications_and_policies/corporate-policies/student-administration/student-records/access-student-records-policy/access-student-records-policy](https://www.education.act.gov.au/publications_and_policies/corporate-policies/student-administration/student-records/access-student-records-policy/access-student-records-policy)

Criminal Law Group. (2025, January 9). *Age Of Consent Australia: Legal Policies, Exceptions, And Laws For Minors*. [https://www.criminallawgroup.com.au/legal-age-of-sexual-dating-consent-australia/](https://www.criminallawgroup.com.au/legal-age-of-sexual-dating-consent-australia/)

LegalVision. (n.d.). *Upcoming Privacy Act Reforms: Major Changes*. [https://legalvision.com.au/upcoming-privacy-act-reforms/](https://legalvision.com.au/upcoming-privacy-act-reforms/)

OAIC. (n.d.). *What is personal information?* [https://www.oaic.gov.au/privacy/your-privacy-rights/what-is-personal-information](https://www.oaic.gov.au/privacy/your-privacy-rights/what-is-personal-information)

OAIC. (n.d.). *Australian Privacy Principles*. [https://www.oaic.gov.au/privacy/australian-privacy-principles](https://www.oaic.gov.au/privacy/australian-privacy-principles)

Victorian Department of Education. (n.d.). *Privacy and Information Sharing: Consent*. [https://www2.education.vic.gov.au/pal/privacy-information-sharing/guidance/consent](https://www2.education.vic.gov.au/pal/privacy-information-sharing/guidance/consent)

The provider code and course code will always be the same.
The provider code changes each year.
The course code is the same for every course that the education provider offers.

correct_answers: The course code will be different for each course that the education provider offers depending on the length and topic of the course. The provider code will always be the same for a certain education provider.

question_results.full_response:
## CRICOS Codes in Australia: Understanding Provider and Course Distinctions

The Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students (CRICOS) is a critical component of Australia's international education framework. It ensures that educational institutions and the courses they offer to international students meet specific quality standards and regulatory requirements ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). Understanding the structure and purpose of CRICOS codes is essential for international students, education providers, and migration agencies alike ([The Migration](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)). This report aims to clarify the relationship between provider codes and course codes within the CRICOS system, drawing upon available information to provide a comprehensive understanding.

**The correct answer is: The course code will be different for each course that the education provider offers depending on the length and topic of the course. The provider code will always be the same for a certain education provider.**

### What is CRICOS?

CRICOS is the official register of Australian education providers permitted to offer courses to students studying in Australia on student visas ([TEQSA](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/cricos-and-elicos/cricos-frequently-asked-questions-faqs)). Registration on CRICOS signifies that an institution and its courses have been vetted and approved by the Australian government, ensuring they meet high academic standards, possess appropriate resources and facilities, and comply with Australian education regulations ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). The system is designed to maintain the integrity and quality of Australia's education sector for international students ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)).

### Structure of a CRICOS Code

A CRICOS code is a unique alphanumeric identifier assigned to each registered course ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). The code typically consists of six digits followed by a letter ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). The first five digits generally identify the specific institution offering the course, while the final digit and letter reference the course itself ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). For example, in the code "123456A," "12345" would represent the institution, and "6A" would be specific to the particular course offered by that institution ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)).

### Provider Code vs. Course Code

The key to understanding the relationship between provider and course codes lies in recognizing their distinct functions:

*   **Provider Code:** This portion of the CRICOS code (typically the first five digits) identifies the educational institution. It remains consistent for all CRICOS-registered courses offered by that specific institution ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). For instance, all courses offered by the University of Sydney that are registered with CRICOS will share a common provider code, which, according to one source, is 00026A ([The Migration](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)).

*   **Course Code:** This part of the CRICOS code (the final digit and letter) is unique to each individual course ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). It differentiates courses based on factors such as their content, duration, and level of study ([Vet Resources](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/what-is-a-cricos-course-code-and-how-to-find-it/)). A Bachelor of Business degree will have a different course code than a Diploma of Information Technology, even if both are offered by the same institution ([Vet Resources](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/what-is-a-cricos-course-code-and-how-to-find-it/)).

### Why CRICOS Codes Matter

CRICOS codes are essential for several reasons:

*   **Quality Assurance:** They guarantee that the course meets national regulatory standards and is recognized by the Australian government ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)).
*   **Visa Eligibility:** Enrolment in a CRICOS-registered course is a requirement for obtaining an Australian student visa ([Vet Resources](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/what-is-a-cricos-course-code-and-how-to-find-it/)).
*   **Informed Decision-Making:** They provide students with comprehensive information about the course, including its name, duration, provider details, and tuition fees ([Vet Resources](https://vetresources.com.au/blog/what-is-a-cricos-course-code-and-how-to-find-it/)).
*   **Institutional Accountability:** CRICOS registration holds education providers accountable for meeting specific standards related to course delivery, student support, and facilities ([ASQA](https://www.asqa.gov.au/news-events/news/reminder-cricos-providers-new-national-code-commenced-1-january-2018)).

### Finding and Verifying CRICOS Codes

International students can easily find and verify CRICOS codes through several channels:

*   **Institution Website:** The CRICOS code is typically listed on the official website of the educational institution ([The Migration](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)).
*   **Promotional Materials:** Brochures and other promotional materials from the institution often include the CRICOS code ([The Migration](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)).
*   **Official CRICOS Website:** The official CRICOS website allows users to search for courses and institutions by name, location, or CRICOS code ([The Migration](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)). The Department of Education provides access to the CRICOS website ([Department of Education](https://www.education.gov.au/esos-framework/resources/cricos-course-codes)).
*   **Direct Contact:** Students can contact the institution directly to obtain the CRICOS code ([The Migration](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)).

### CRICOS Registration: An Ongoing Process

CRICOS registration is not a one-time event ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). Institutions must regularly renew their registration and undergo assessments to ensure ongoing compliance with Australian education standards ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). This continuous monitoring helps maintain the high quality of international education in Australia and protects the country's reputation as a premier destination for overseas students ([CAQA Compliance](https://caqa.com.au/blogs/news/cricos-course-codes-your-key-to-high-quality-international-education-in-australia)). Providers must notify TEQSA of changes to their CRICOS registration details ([TEQSA](https://www.teqsa.gov.au/cricos-and-elicos/notifications-and-approvals-required-cricos-registered-providers)).

### Implications for Migration Agencies

Migration agencies must verify the CRICOS registration of educational institutions before recommending them to clients ([The Migration](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)). Partnering with unregistered institutions can damage the agency's reputation and erode client trust ([The Migration](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)). By recommending CRICOS-registered courses and institutions, agencies can ensure that their clients receive a high-quality education that meets Australian government standards ([The Migration](https://themigration.com.au/blog/cricos-code-australia-a-comprehensive-guide/)).

### Conclusion

In summary, the CRICOS system is a cornerstone of Australia's international education framework. While the provider code remains constant for a given institution, the course code is unique to each program, reflecting differences in content, duration, and level of study. International students must understand the distinction between provider and course codes to make informed decisions about their education and visa options. By utilizing the resources available on the official CRICOS website and consulting with education agents, students can navigate the system effectively and ensure a rewarding and legally compliant study experience in Australia.
